More than  MPs have already mulled chucking their hats in the ring to replace her. Unlike Mrs Mayaposs election in , where Tory members never voted, this race promises to be the most bruising in years. And just like her election, it will have profound consequences for Brexit - with a hard-right, Hard Leaver likely to take the reins. Possible candidates have been shamelessly jostling for position, holding secretive dinners, parading their families and doing puffy newspaper interviews in a bid to scoop up support. Some have even declared openly, with Boris Johnson booming: Iaposm going to go for it!  Under the rules of a Tory leadership race, candidates bidding for the crown must be nominated by two or more fellow Tory MPs. A series of knockout ballots is then held among MPs to whittle down the wide field of candidates to just two.  Those two preferred candidates go to a run-off of the wider Conservative Party, with its , members eligible to vote. The candidate who wins the most votes becomes the leader.  So, as the formal leadership contest begins, who are the people lining up to try and be your next Prime Minister  Weaposve looked at all the runners and riders, the frontrunnersapos odds and how much of a True Blue Tory Warrior™ they are.    All the Tory leadership contenders Declared openly that they want to runBoris Johnson Esther McVey Rory Stewart Jeremy HuntReported, hinted - or refused to rule outAndrea Leadsom Amber Rudd Matt Hancock Michael Gove Dominic RaabJames Cleverly Kit Malthouse Sajid Javid Penny Mordaunt Liz Truss Mark Harper David Gauke James Brokenshire Steve Baker Graham Brady Johnny Mercer Justine Greening Tom TugendhatThose who say they definitely WONaposT be runningDavid Lidington Jacob Rees-Mogg Tobias Ellwood David Davis Victoria Atkins Ken Clarke Dominic GrieveThe bookiesapos frontrunners Odds retrieved from Paddy Power, th May  Boris Johnson ODDS:  VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING:    Brexiteer and former foreign secretary Mr Johnson, , has been a leading voice against Theresa Mayaposs Brexit plan - and heaposs been preparing for this for years. The Old Etonian was one of the key players in the  Leave campaign after a last-minute decision to back Brexit. He resigned from the Cabinet in  in protest at Mayaposs plan. He was tipped as a successor to David Cameron but ruled himself out after Michael Gove stabbed him in the back with a last-minute bid for the top job. Since then heaposs lost weight and had a haircut in what many argued was a pre-leadership bid upgrade. Sure enough he confirmed by telling a business conference: Iaposm going to go for it! Selecting the former mayor of London for eight years would enrage Tory Remainers, who believe he is in this game only for himself and his ego. He became notorious for his attention-grabbing offensive comments, when he called black people piccaninnies, said Barack Obama was part-Kenyan and compared the EU to Adolf Hitler. But scores of Tory MPs would vote for Anyone But Boris and a Scottish operation to stop him was nicknamed Operation Arse. Dominic Raab ODDS:   VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING: .   During his four-month stint as Brexit Secretary, ultra-hard Leaver Dominic Raab suggested he would use leaving the EU to slash business taxes. Now heaposs running for leader heaposs hinted p could be slashed off income tax - cutting billions from the public purse. And that wasnapost all that would anger left-wingers. The -year-old sparked fury in  by saying most food bank users are not languishing in poverty. He claimed: The typical user... is someone who has a cash flow problem. When a disability activist told him people are dying under Tory austerity, he described her calls for cash as a childish wish list. And he put out a pamphlet in  that suggested exempting small firms from minimum wage laws for workers under . Mr Raab positioned himself early on for the leadership, setting out his plans to tackle kne crime with “robust policing” and community work. He also paraded in his home in a cringeworthy interview with his we. And he attempted to outflank hostile competition by addressing claims he used a gagging order, to silence a former colleague who accused him of bullying. Mr Raab told The Sunday Times the claims, which date back to  before he was an MP, were completely ”. And he kept his powder dry in the days immediately following Theresa Mayaposs announcement she would quit. But behind the scenes his allies, including Treasury minister Mel Stride, have been approaching MPs in the most unlikely positions to seethey will join his slate. One former Cabinet minister told the Mirror Mr Gove was one of the most likely to be elected. Despite infuriating teachers when he was Education Secretary, and stabbing Boris Johnson in the back for leadership in , the -year-old is seen as a competent media performer and has won plaudits as a campaigner for environmental issues. He has already paraded with his Scottish parents as part of the proxy leadership contest in the party. He was a prominent face in the Brexit campaign, but he isnapost wildly trusted by other figures on the Conservativesapos eurosceptic wing.    Jeremy Hunt ODDS:   VOTED: Remain TRUE BLUE RATING:    Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt was a prominent Remainer in the  referendum. He chose not to run in the  leadership contest and instead gave his full support to Mrs May, saying it was not the right time to put his hat in the ring. Mr Hunt made a public sht towards Euroscepticism after the referendum.    Andrea Leadsom ODDS:   VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING:    The -year-old, grammar-school educated former bank executive is about as true blue Tory as you can get. She survived to the final two of the  Tory leadership race, pitching herself as the Hard Brexit, blue alternative to Theresa May with a cringeworthy march in Westminster. But she infamously pulled out after making controversial remarks about motherhood and trying to deny them. She has said she is seriously considering running for the leadership again. And she played a crucial part in forcing Theresa Mayaposs resignation announcement, after resigning from the PMaposs cabinet and blasting her Brexit plan just hours before the EU elections.    Penny Mordaunt ODDS:   VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING:    Recently promoted to Defence Secretary, Penny Mordaunt is a -year-old Royal Navy reservist whoaposs only been an MP since  - but has a rich slew of headlines to her name. From bellyflopping on TV ing show Splash! to slashing billions off benefits and lying about Brexit, sheaposs often been famous - and only sometimes for the right reasons. The daughter of a paratrooper and special needs teacher, who has a twin brother, the Portsmouth North MP went to her local comprehensive. She worked in a factory and as a magicianaposs assistant to save up for Reading University, which she was the first member of her family to go to. The PR supremo was director of communications for the National Lottery, head of campaigns for Diabetes UK, head of foreign press for George W Bush’s  and  election campaigns and chief of staff for former MP David Willetts.    Rory Stewart ODDS:   VOTED: Remain TRUE BLUE RATING:    The Hong Kong-born son of a diplomat, an Old Etonian, once admitted his career gives the appearance he was a spy. The International Development Secretary wasted absolutely no time after being promoted to the Cabinet in May . He announced his pitch to be PM within hours. Mr Stewart said: I think itaposs important at this time when the Prime Ministeraposs said sheaposs going to step down to have a voice thataposs arguing for being radical. Yet his approach - blindly following the PMaposs Brexit deal and saying it might even be worth splitting the party for - has made him wildly unpopular among Tory Brexiteers.    Sajid Javid  ODDS:   VOTED: Remain TRUE BLUE RATING:    The Home Secretary has spent a few months warming up for a leadership bid. It’s widely expected the next Tory leader will be a Brexiteer. Meaning Mr Javid, , who backed Reman but now supports Leave, would have a real fight on his hands to win round Tory members. He took over at the Home Office after Amber Rudd was forced to quit over the Windrush scandal - and has picked public fights with Mrs May on key issues like immigration and police funding. But his star has fallen over chaotic handling of migrants crossing the Channel. He was accused of stoking tensions by declaring a national emergency to deal with a few hundred migrant crossings over a period of months. Mr Javid, the son of Pakistani bus driver, would be the first non-white Prime Minister. Matt Hancock ODDS:   VOTED: Remain TRUE BLUE RATING: .     The ambitious -year-old entered politics as George Osborneaposs adviser and was in the inner circle of the famously cliquey ex-Chancellor. The parkour- and karaoke-loving Conservative entered Parliament in , Government in  and joined the DCMS in July  after Mrs May took over as Prime Minister. Within days of the PMaposs announcement, he somehow found his way onto the Good Morning Britain sofa, where he said of leadership: I think you don’t rule out these things.” Then, all but confirming he would run, he posed with a horse. James Cleverly ODDS:   VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING:    The -year-old Brexiteer is a tub-thumping Tory whoaposs not afraid to go into battle on social media. The MP for Braintree has repeatedly got into spats with Labour since taking his job as Tory Vice Chair. Heaposs a boisterous character at social events and in the bars of Parliament, making up for a lack of Westminster experiencewith fierce public loyalty. Esther McVey  ODDS:   VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING:   The hardline Brexiteer confirmed she will be running for the Tory leadership with a pledge to slash £billion from foreign aid, and spend it on schools and the police. The former welfare-slasher and rank outsider said: Iaposve always said quite clearlyI got enough support from colleagues then yes I would, and now people have come forward and I have got that support. But former GMTV presenter Ms McVey became notorious among benefit claimants after working as a Minister and later Secretary of State in the Department for Work and Pensions. Her blunt style drew floods of criticism even when she managed to secure limited extra money for cash-starved Universal Credit, and U-turned on a benefit cut for the disabled.  Over the years, she made a number of controversial comments which turned her into a lightning rod for anger about benefits. But as the party has drted to the right the moderate Remainer Ms Rudd had fallen out of favour. She was forced to quit as Home Secretary during the Windrush scandal. story: NewsopinionTheresa May resigns: Profile of the plastic Thatcher act who drove herself to downfallThere were always two Theresa Mays - and in the end, she failed to embody either of them, writes Head of Politics Jason BeattieShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  MAY Newsopinionthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video theresa-announced-departure-prime-minister-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThere were always two Theresa Mays. There was the vicar’s daughter with a strong sense of public duty who wanted to do her best for the country. And there was the plastic Thatcher act the dogmatic Tory who understood the world only through the prism of her Home Counties upbringing. In the end she failed to live up to either role. Her premiership limped to its sad end because, ultimately, she was a mediocre, narrow and unimaginative politician. There was no great vision of where she wanted to take the country and she did not have the statecraft necessary to see through Brexit.    In the end the only quality associated with Mrs May was a plodding resilience and even that had a limited shelf le. All her limitations were there to see from her time in the Home Office. For six years she cocooned herself in the Department fearful of any grand gesture which might attract attention. There were a couple of small but totemic successes - the deportation of Abu Hamza and the Modern Slavery Act - which she clung to as evidence she had used her time effectively. But there was no great reform. The only major policy change was the introduction of Police and Crime Commissioners who the public like so much that barely % turned out to vote from them.    The rest of her legacy from the Home Office was rising numbers in immigration despite the pledge to cap net migration to the tens of thousands and cuts to police numbers which have resulted in a rise in violent crime. The woman who had accused the Tories of being the “nasty party” oversaw the “hostile environment” that led to the Windrush scandal.  By hiding in the Home Office, Mrs May managed to avoid scrutiny over whether she was suited for the top job. Her hallmarks of timidity coupled with political calculation where displayed again during the EU referendum when she did the bare minimum to back the Remain campaign. The person who was to later ask the country to act in the national interest acted in her personal interest by concluding her soft opposition to Brexit would help her win over Tory leave MPs in any leadership campaign.    When the vacancy did emerge in June  Mrs May managed to enter No  without a vote thanks to the incompetence of Boris Johnson, the Treachery of Michael Gove and the inadequacy of Andrea Leadsom. Speaking on the steps of Downing Street for the first time as Prime Minister, Mrs May promised to end the “burning injustices” afflicting Britain. Perhaps she meant it. The intentions may have been noble but as so often with Mrs May the words were never matched by the deeds. On her watch austerity continued, the number of people in absolute poverty continued to rise and rough sleeping has more than doubled. While her domestic agenda proved disappointing, her handling of Brexit was calamitous.  Desperate to keep her party together after the referendum she appointed a string of Brexiteers to key positions for which they were either unworthy or unqualied. Boris Johnson, who had a made a career out of insulting foreigners, was put in the Foreign Office Chris Grayling’s failures as Justice Secretary were rewarded with a gig as Transport Secretary and David Davis was made Brexit Secretary despite his apparent aversion to detail. Then the mistakes began to mount up. In her first conference speech as Prime Minister she set out her unilateral ambition for Brexit based on the red lines of ending freedom of movement and reclaiming sovereignty from European Court of Justice. Within months she triggered Article  without any clear negotiating objective.  She was so confident that she declared we would have a new trade deal with the EU by March . In case anyone was in any doubt this was a Brexit only for the % who voted Leave she insulted Remain voters as being “citizens of nowhere.” She then attempted to sideline Parliament by denying them a vote on Article  only to have to reverse the decision after losing a Supreme Court judgement. All May’s worst traits were on display: she was furtive, distrusting of colleagues and over controlling. Ken Clarke famously dubbed her a “bloody dficult woman”. This was supposed to a back-handed compliment to Mrs May’s obstinacy but it more accurately refers to her inability to communicate and refusal to accept new ideas.  It was never clearher stubbornness was born of resilience or from an absence of imagination. Then she called the General Election after repeatedly saying there would be no snap poll. The disastrous campaign was notable for her “Maybot” performance and the u-turn on the dementia tax after which she forlornly claimed “nothing has changed.” When the election result came in everything did change. She was forced to sack her aides Nick Timothy and Fiona Hill, bribe the DUP for its support and sacrice the whip hand on Brexit. A dismal year was capped with her pitul conference speech where in space of an hour she managed to lose her voice, was handed a P by a prankster and suffer the humiliation of the lettering fall off the backstop.  Somehow she managed to soldier on. The red lines on Brexit were erased, ministers resigned in droves and Parliament took back control. In the end Mrs May could hide no longer. Her botched Brexit deal, failure to be candid about its consequences and inability to keep her party united combined to bring about her downfall. Mrs May claimed she never wanted to be remembered for Brexit but it begs the question of why she took the job in the first place given it was inevitably going to dominate her premiership. It was a thankless task but one she asked for.

title: watched theresa mays teary speech
story: NewsAnalysisI watched Theresa Mays teary speech - it was even more uncomfortable in personSKETCH: The Prime Minister almost managed to keep it together during her seven-minute speech outside No. The Mirrors Ben Glaze watched the historic momentShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsAnalysisTheresa May announced she would resign "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAt .am Philip May, in a dark blue suit, walked out of No with the Prime Minister’s senior aides and stepped into Downing Street. Two minutes later his we emerged from No and confidently strode to the wooden lectern bearing the Government crest. Armed police guarded both ends of the street as two union flags fluttered proudly in the cloudless, late spring sky. Earlier, Westminster’s two cats, Larry from No and Palmerston from the Foreign Office, posed for waiting journalists.    And in a bizarre coincidence, in the security hut where visitors are screened, armed police were doing a brown envelope whip round for a colleague who is leaving. As a battery of cameras clicked and Sky News’ helicopter clattered above, the PM reeled off what she believes were her greatest hits: house building, the Grenfell Tower inquiry and tackling national debt. But she also conceded she had failed to deliver Brexit. With dozens of lenses pointed at her face, she occasionally lted her glance towards the barrage, unfaltering in her speech. But as her seven-minute address neared its end, and she spoke of being the second woman PM, her voice began to give as she blinked back tears in the strong sunshine.    As she climaxed and stressed her “enormous and enduring gratitude to have had the opportunity to serve the country I love”, her voice collapsed to a wail. It was a deeply uncomfortable public show of emotion from this most introvert and private of women. Philip, his hands clasped behind his back, must have been in knots watching his we implode under the media’s glare. How dferent from July , , when he beamed as she told of her ambition to confront the country’s “burning injustices”. In a grotesque reminder of the issue that haunted and has now doomed her premiership, the PM turned and walked back toward the black door as a lone protester at the gates shouted: “Stop Brexit!”

title: what happens now theresa resigns
story: NewsWhat happens now Theresa May has resigned - and what it means for BrexitTheresa May has finally named a date for her departure - but the Brexit bedlam may just be beginning. Heres what happens nextShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political EditorOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video who-could-replace-theresa-tory-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTearful Theresa May has finally announced the date for her resignation after bowing to months of Tory mutiny over Brexit. So what happens now the Plastic Thatcher Act who failed to tackle burning injustices has quit  Once she officially hands in her notice on Friday  June, a sequence of events will be set in train to confirm her replacement. But sheaposll remain Prime Minister for several weeks while that process is carried out. Her successor can take the wheel of Brexit without going to the country - but could be forced to,thereaposs worse deadlock in Parliament. Jeremy Corbyn demanded an immediate general election. Hereaposs what happens when Theresa May quits - and answers to more questions about the aftermath.  Theresa May will officially resign as leader of the Conservative Party on Friday  June. But she will remain caretaker Prime Minister during a Tory leadership contest, which will to start the following week and finish in late July. That means a new Prime Minister will take over just before MPsapos summer recess, three months before the current Brexit deadline of October . Only then will Mrs May stand down as Prime Minister, going to the Queen to formally resign and invite the monarch to nominate her successor. This follows the model of David Cameron, who remained in office during the race to replace him, which Mrs May won in .  Theresa May delayed her decision until after the State Visit to the UK by Donald Trump on June -, and D-Day anniversary events on June . This avoids the unseemly sight of Britainaposs leadership being undermined during a visit by a foreign power. However, past experience tells us that may well not stop Trump throwing a grenade into the debate anyway - perhaps by endorsing a leadership contender like Boris Johnson, who heaposs praised as a future PM before. How will the Conservatives pick the next leader   A leadership contest is expected to take about six weeks. Candidates must be nominated by two sitting Conservative MPs. Firstly, votes are held among Conservative MPs to whittle the field down to two. In each vote, the candidate with the least support is eliminated. These votes will start in the week of June . Traditionally these happen on Tuesdays and Thursdays while Parliament is sitting. But the Toriesapos  Committee - which runs the contest - can shorten these intervals.  Once there are two candidates, they are both put to a ballot of the Tory membership - around , or so people - to choose the new leader. A new leader will be in place before MPsapos summer recess. How does this affect Brexit   Brexit is still due on October  - and the decision to hold a leadership election makes No Deal more likely. Weeks after EU chief Donald Tusk begged us please donapost waste this time, weaposre set to have a new Prime Minister who could steer Brexit in a much harder direction. Tory members are widely expected to elect a Brexiteer Prime Minister who will either try to crash out with no deal, or act the strongman with Brussels to get a better deal. The problem is, not only has Brussels refused to go further - there also simply isnapost a majority for this in Parliament. Her successor will inherit the same deeply ided Parliament, where MPs are implacably opposed to a No Deal Brexit , with no majority without the support of the Northern Irish DUP. Technically No Deal Brexit is the legal default, even though MPs have voted against it. So a new PM could try and plough forward into No Deal, but would face parliamentary mutiny and a constitutional crisis. The paralysis that grips Parliament wonapost disappear just because Theresa May does. Will there be a general election   Not yet, and a new PM can take power without one. But itaposs become more likely all the same. Thataposs because the deadlock in Parliamentwill deepen even furthera hard Brexiteer takes power. The new PM could be forced to try and win a new majority. Or in an extreme situation, the deadlock could push some Tory MPs to vote no confidence in their own government. Last time , a no confidence vote failed by  MPs. Enough defectors and it could pass. Jeremy Corbyn could attempt another no confidence vote in the government after he called for an immediate general election. Itaposd be an uphill struggle as the Toriesapos DUP allies and Change UK have suggested they wonapost back him. But Labouraposs leader said: She cannot govern, and nor can her ided and disintegrating party.  “The Conservative Party has utterly failed the country over Brexit and is unable to improve people’s lives or deal with their most pressing needs. Will there be a second referendum   Itaposs not on the table at the moment. While the forthcoming leadership contest will make calls for it louder, practically, it will also put it on the back burner. Theresa May had offered a parliamentary route to a binding referendum as her final desperate pitch at compromise. That route has now gone up in smoke. Who are the frontrunners to replace Theresa May   Boris Johnson is the favourite - triggering furious machinations among aposmoderateapos or Remainer Tories. Many accept the Marmite-like millionaire wins votes despite being a gaffe-prone offence machine who makes deliberately insulting comments for attention. Remainer Tories are trying to convince Mr Johnson - who backed Brexit in  after great personal turmoil - to steer away from No Deal and promise to negotiate with the EU, so they have a fig leaf of an excuse to support him. It a crowded field and former Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab and Jeremy Hunt are also seen as challengers, with Mr Hunt reportedly Mrs Mayaposs favourite to replace her.   No, sheaposll carry on as an MP, according to her constituency chairman. The Prime Minister rang Richard Kellaway this morning before her resignation statement. He said: “The main concern for us as her association is that she’s not going to resign her seat. She will carry on as a Member of Parliament, which is welcomed by us. “As the Prime Minister, she could go to the House of Lordsshe wants to go that route and carry on, or she could stay a member of Parliament. “Quite clearly, it’s a very troubling and dficult time for her and she’ll need to settle down and see what she wants to do.” Odds on the next Prime Minister Boris Johnson:   Dominic Raab:   Michael Gove:   Jeremy Hunt:   Andrea Leadsom:    Penny Mordaunt:   Rory Stewart:   Sajid Javid:   Matt Hancock:   James Cleverly:   Esther McVey:   Amber Rudd:   Liz Truss:

title: you not heard man historical
story: NewsYou may not have heard of this man - but his historical election triumph will affect youNarendra Modi, leader of the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, vowed ato “achhe din” – or good times – and projected himself as the only one who could ensure the nation’s securityShareCommentsByMatt Roper:,  MAY News delivers a speech during a rally ahead of Phase VI of Indias general election in New Delhi on May , . - The Delhi-NCRwill go to the polls on May  during Phase VI of Indias general election." content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _I__oTextTRMRMMGLPICTo.jpg"It was a historical day "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailYou may not have heard of the man who has just won the largest election in history – but his triumph could affect you in ways you may never imagine. Over six weeks of voting, which ended yesterday, more than  million Indians cast their ballots, using more than . million polling machines and overseen by  million officials. The staggering scale of the operation in the world’s largest democracy was dwarfed only by surprise at the result, a landslide for premier Narendra Modi. Modi, leader of the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, should have faced a ­drubbing at the polls. Joblessness had risen to a -year high under him, along with plummeting incomes for most workers and a damaging slump in industrial production.  But, reflecting of the rise of nationalism worldwide, the -year-old appealed to patriotism and fed on fear. He vowed ato “achhe din” – or good times – and projected himself as the only one who could ensure the nation’s security. In fact many have likened him to another nationalist, US President Donald Trump. While Trump won votes by his tough talk on Mexico, Modi presented himself as the strongman in relations with India’s neighbour Pakistan.  Like Trump, he has been criticised for often distasteful attacks on his rivals or critics. And just like the isive US president, he speak directly to the people through social media. Taking another page out of Trump’s playbook, Modi has also been accused of whipping up nationalist feelings, stoking religious and social tensions and even inciting violence against Muslims and others. During his campaign, Amit Shah, the party’s president, called Muslim migrants who enter the country illegally “termites”. The BJP has also been accused of stoking hysteria against Muslims and low-caste Hindus for not respecting cows– sacred to Hindus. As a result, Hindu mobs have attacked and lynched Muslims for supposedly eating beef. Among BJP candidates elected yesterday with a landslide was Pagya Thakur, accused of plotting a bomb attack on Indian Muslims.  But why should we care that a man like Modi has just become India’s most powerful leader since Indira Gandhi  First, India is expected to become the third largest economy by  .Britain has been counting on our old empire ties to secure a post-Brexit free trade deal, and Theresa May has been busily wooing Modi.But emboldened with the first majority government in India for  years, could Modi take a cue from Trump’s protectionism and block a deal that is good for Britain  Last year he raised import tarfs on  items, including gemstones, jet fuel, plastics, home appliances and shoes, in a bid to protect India’s industries. For Adam Ziegfeld, professor of political science at Temple University, Philadelphia, his landslide win will have “empowered” Modi in trade dealings with Britain and other nations. He said: “It will mean he can focus on economic growth and a muscular foreign policy, making sure India has a wider impact.  “The fact he has raised tarfs on imports gives some idea of the direction he might take.”Another reason it matters who runs India is because it is a nuclear power, involved in along-running conflict in Kashmir. This is behind tension withnuclear-armed Pakistan.The Federation of American Scientists estimates India has between  and  nuclear warheads. It also possesses the technology to send a nuclear warhead , miles on its Agni-V rockets. Many fear that a man who has sabre-rattled about Pakistan now has his finger even more firmly on the nuclear button. Those concerned about the climate crisis should also take heed. India is the third-biggest C polluter. A study in  found it was overtaking China as the largest emitter of sulphur dioxide. Twenty-two of the world’s  most polluted cities are in India. Ziegfeld said Modi will now be “more assertive about his stance that ‘you polluted your way to industrialisation, and now you’re telling us to change ’” Perhaps the most immediate worry, however, is for the ethnic and religious minorities. He said: “A pro-Hindu, anti-Muslim sentiment has run through Indian politics but this is the first time a party has really embraced it. From the point of view of  million Muslims, their victory is not good. “An awful lot of people feel in a very precarious position.”

story: NewsGran, , told to leave her £.m home after losing court fight with her daughterJane Habberfield, from Yeovil, Somerset, now finds herself in a "desperately dficult situation," Londons Appeal Court heardShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsJane Habberfield, , attended the hearing at Londons Appeal Court "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A grandmother will be booted out her own home after a losing ruinously expensive court fight with her youngest daughter.Jane Habberfield, , has been in a dispute with Lucy, , since her dad Frank died in .Londonaposs Appeal Court heard today Jane now finds herself in a desperately dficult situation as sheaposll be turned out her £.million country home.Lucy, who grafted long hours on their family farm for  years - including doing -hour weeks milking cows when she was heavily pregnant - sued her mum after Jane refused to hand her ownership of the farm following Frankaposs death. The mum, described in court as her dadaposs blue-eyed girl, said her parents had promised she would be given the farm and last year a judge ordered Jane to pay Lucy over £. million to compensate her for devoting her le to the family holding and the cows.    And Jane lost her appeal against that order today. Lord Justice Lewison said: This is a sad tale of a farming family The Habberfields. In order to raise the cash sum to which the judge held Lucy to be entitled, the whole of the farm would have to be sold. On the face of it, it seems hard that an -year-old woman should leave the house which has been her home for over  years. On the other side of the scale, Lucy was  at the date of trial.    She wanted to begin farming on her own account before it was too late. Without access to the cash award, she would not be able to do so. Lucyaposs expectation was not such as would require her mother to leave the farmhouse. But that expectation was predicated on the continuation of a harmonious family relationship not on the aftermath of a ruinously expensive litigation in which her claim was denied. Although Jane is elderly, she might live for many years. In view of the family breakdown it was also highly desirable for there to be a clean break. The judge heard tensions had been already building between mum Jane, Lucy and her sister Sarah - who a judge found all have a temper - before a scrap between the sisters in a cowshed at -acre Woodrow Farm, near Yeovil, Somerset, pushed things to crisis point.  This led to Lucy storming out of the family holding where she had worked since she was a schoolgirl, and subsequently filing a court claim for the farm she said she was promised. Sarah attended the hearing and backed her elderly mother. But the High Court last year heard Lucy carried out gruelling physical work for long hours with early starts when she was heavily pregnant or had young babies to care for in the s. Lucy told the court she never had a good relationship with her mother. But she was their late dad Frankaposs favourite and blue-eyed girl because of their shared passion for dairy farming, the court was told.

title: kenneth noye m25 hatton garden
story: NewsM killer Kenneth Noyes underworld links to the Hatton Garden jewellery heistKenneth Noye, one the countrys most notorious and violent gangsters, has been granted parole despite killing two men and has links to Hatton Garden robber, Brian Reader, which stretch back four decadesShareBySteve MyallDeputy Features Editor:,  MAY NewsM killer Kenneth Noye will soon be released on parole "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEarly one morning in November  six robbers broke into the Brinkaposs-Mat warehouse, Unit  of the Heathrow International Trading Estate near Heathrow Airport. Once inside they poured petrol over staff and threatened them with a lit matchthey did not reveal the combination numbers of the vault.They were after £.million in cash but instead they found three tonnes of gold bullion as well as diamonds and cash worth the equivalent of £million today. It was dubbed the crime of the century.But there was one big problem - how to spend a gold bar, especially one thataposs obviously stolen.    They enlisted he help of letime criminal Kenneth Noye and fellow villian Brian Reader, who had access to equipment for smelting. He was the reason undercover police officers John Fordham and Neil Murphy were dressed in camouflage clothes and balaclavas outside Noyeaposs Kent mansion months later. Scotland Yard suspected gold was being taken to Noyeaposs estate in West Kingsdown but were unsure how it was being transported to and from the house. The suspicion was that an associate of Noyeaposs, Brian Reader, was involved. Reader was jailed last year for his part in the Hatton Garden jewellery heist and was a friend of Noye. The senior detective who investigated Brink’s-Mat, Brian Boyce, told one reporter that “Reader was trusted by Noye” and was also close to other major crime figures such as the London-based Adams crime family.    When Reader’s home was raided by police they found a book on the diamond underworld, a diamond tester, a diamond gauge, diamond magazines.  The officers had arrived to do the night sht, pm to am and almost immediately, a car turned up and they realised Reader was going in. They moved closer - climbing over the fence and into the grounds of the property - but Noyeaposs three Rottweiler guard dogs started barking at them and pulling at their clothes. Detective Murphy indicated he was going to retreat back to the fence but the officers were then separated. When Det Murphy went back to look for his partner, who was at the time regarded as the countryaposs top undercover policeman, he found him lying a few yards inside the gate having been stabbed  times. At the subsequent murder trial of Noye and Reader the court heard his dying words were  He has done me - he has stabbed me. As Detective Constable Fordham spoke, a man pointing a shotgun at police backed away towards the house.  Noye, was said to have told police He should not be on my property, I hope he f****** dies. While Det Murphy was watching he heard someone shout: Show us your ID or I will blow your head off. He also saw a man aim a kick at the body of his partner. After the killing, Noye is alleged to have told police: F*** off or Iaposll do you as well.Later, he was arrested inside the house and admitted arming himself with a kitchen kne. Askedhe had stabbed Fordham he is alleged to have replied: Yeah - I did him before he took the kne from me. During the questioning one officer lost his temper and flew at Noye and had to be restrained. Noye was charged with murder along with Brian Reader but acquitted in December  after an  day trial after they claimed they acted in self defence He told the jury: God bless you forever, because that is what I am, not guilty. The pair did not escape jail though as during the aftermath of the killing police recovered  gold bars worth about £,, a sackful of copper coins used in smelting, and a Guinness World Records book with the entry on the Brinks Mat robbery circled.    The following year he was jailed for handling stolen gold from the from the raid and this time did not have such kind words for the jury, shouting: “I hope you all die of cancer” as he was sent down for  years. It transpired he first melted the Brinkaposs Mat gold, then added copper to it, and re-shaped it.It was then ready to sell back through the legitimate, bullion markets... with a  per cent VAT charge. Noye was released from prison in , having served eight years but in a civil action brought by the loss adjusters of Brinkaposs-Mat insurers was forced to pay £million while he was incarcerated.Much of the money from the original raid has never been traced. Reader was jailed for nine years. Two years after being released on licence he was involved in a altercation with Stephen Cameron, , after he cut up a van driven by his girlfriend on a junction on the M. In a fight Noye stabbed and killed Cameron with a kne. This time he knew self-defence was going to be harder to convince a jury of and fled abroad by private plane. Police caught up with him in Spain and he was extradited and found guilty of murder in  but is now expected to be freed any day. His Brinks Matt co-conspirator Reader, , was released from prison last year after serving three years of a six years and three months sentence for conspiracy to commit burglary in relation to to the Hatton Garden theft.

title: lucky mums stark car seat
story: NewsMums urgent car seat warning after son is almost internally decapitatedCara Steele has warned other parents about the proper way to use childrens car seats after her a truck ploughed into her Vauxhall Astra Estate near Chapel en le Frith, DerbyshireShareByBradley JollyEmma Gill:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsCara Steele, , pictured with her son, has warned other parents about kids car seats "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn -month-old toddler avoided decapitation in a crash - because his relieved mum had kept his car seat rear facing. Little Albie Steele somehow left the shunt with just cuts and bruises on Monday.    A pickup truck smashed into the back of Cara Steeleaposs Vauxhall Astra Estate, Manchester Evening News says. But a paramedic and a traffic officer told Cara, , thatAlbie had been front facing, it would have been a very dferent scenario - severe spinal injury or even internal decapitation where the spinal cord is severed from the force of the impact. Cara has shared haunting photos of the aftermath of the crash to warn other parents. If this makes one person consider extended rear facing, or turning their child back to rear facing then my story has helped somebody.    Albie is only  months old but he will rear face until he’s kg. There’s so much information out there about the benefits of rear facing, I only ask that people educate themselves with it, the teacher, from Chapel en le Frith, Derbyshire, said. Authorities stress little ones must sit in rear-facing car seats until they reach the recommended kg, or lb - up to around six years old. Two men helped get Albie out, while Cara got out through the passenger door. Cara, a mum-of-one, needed an X-ray on her spine and shoulder but it thankfully showed no fractures. She added: Albie had a couple of bruises on his leg, a small cut on his eye and on one of his legs, which we think came from the glass, but very superficial.  He’s only  months so it’s hard to say fully how he is as he can’t communicate with us. We can assume he has been aching as he will have had some force from the impact. We’ve had a couple of wake ups in the night which isn’t usual for him, but have been doing paracetamol and ibruprofen and that seems to be fine. He was asleep when the truck hit, which means he would have been as relaxed as possible, which will have helped with whiplash too. We were told thathe had been forward facing he would have risked severe spinal injury or even internal decapitation. The teacher said it took a while to realise just how fortunate theyaposd been.  She went on: I think adrenalin just takes over and all I cared about was him. It was only when I sat down in someone’s house that took us in that I realised I was so sore and bruised and then when I walked outside a couple of hours later and saw the car I think it really hit me. The car was an estate so thank God for the huge boot space. The boot was completely gone so it could have been devastating in a smaller car. For maximum safety, parents are advised to keep children in rear facing car seats until fully outgrown - crossing their legsneeds be and taking frequent breaks during long journeys. Derbyshire Police said a -year-old man was arrested at the scene of Mondayaposs incident and has been charged with one count of aggravated vehicle taking and one count of driving without insurance.

The song was backed up by a rap about parents who never saw their children because they had to work so many jobs.Under pressure from a church primary school in one of the country’s most deprived areas, City Airport, currently in the middle of a £million ­expansion plan, decided topay up.Introducing the independently calculated London Living Wage of £. an hour from July means a £,-a-year pay rise for contractors, including cleaners and security staff.  With over % of the staff living within five miles of the runway, the children are in no doubt who will benefit. “Our parents will be less stressed than before,” head girl Zeruiah Adomake, , tells me. “We can go on school trips, our lunch meals will be better. We’ll get more time with our families because our parents won’t always be working.” Adam Hakkowski, , nods. “Parents can get presents for their children on their birthdays,” he says. Other children talk about having a hot meal or being able to go to the cinema or even save for a holiday when their parents are paid properly. This week the school found out they have been shortlisted for a Living Wage Champion Award with Newham Citizens. “This fight was David and Goliath,” deputy head Yvonne Wade tells me. “It was a small school in a deprived area of East London and the bosses of London City Airport. “But they were ­determined, even in the face of power, sat in big leather chairs, speaking to smart-looking men in suits. Do not be fooled by these kids’ smiles. These are tough cookies.” Supported by TELCO, the East London Citizens ­Organisation, St Antony’s Living Wage campaign began with a survey done by Year  pupils of the local church and school population. “Our survey found that almost half of parents earned less than the Living Wage,” Ms Wade says. “No wonder families couldn’t get a proper meal on the table, or spend enough time together.  “There was a need for change. We told City Airport: ‘No is not an option, we can’t wait’. And we won.” Alistair Rooms at TELCO said the speed with which the airport has responded is impressive. And the airport’s corporate director, Liam McKay, who visited the school, said: “London City Airport will be proud to be the first UK airport to pay the London Living Wage this summer.“That decision was undoubtedly influenced by the powerful ­advocacy from thebrilliant pupils of St Antony’s in our home borough of Newham.”Angela Moore, the head teacher, tells the school assembly: “Education is not just about teaching maths and English, science and RE. It’s about what we do with what we learn. “We don’t want our pupils to feel ashamed. We want our pupils to feel ­empowered. “You have made your presence felt in one of the poorest wards in London. “Your parents benefit directly from what you have achieved. You’ve made your futures brighter and more secure.”The children performed their song at the Barbican Centre in front of the Mayor of London, Sadiq Khan , who backed their campaign all the way.They were mentored by Alistair from TELCO, Olawale Ajibola, , a cleaner who helped win the London Living Wage at the London Stadium – formerly the Olympic stadium and now home to West Ham – and Sister Una McCreesh, , from the Ursuline Convent at Forest Gate. At , Sister Una is one of the veterans of the Living Wage campaign, and was moved to start campaigning for decent wages when she was a head teacher in Newham.  One day a child had written in his book that his mother was dead. It turned out he meant that she was working three jobs and he never saw her. “We wanted to persuade HSBC to pay the living wage as it was a very big local employer,” Sister Una says. “They wouldn’t give us a meeting, so we took in the collection plate money into their busiest branch in Holborn. “We have about , ­parishioners so that collection plate money was taking a long time to put through. That tied up one teller, and the other teller had a queue of people saying they would like to open a bank account. “So, there were ­enormous queues and eventually the police were called, but we weren’t breaking any laws, of course,” she smiles politely. “We got a meeting eventually, and after that the banks started to move on wages.” Next week, Sister Una will win a Letime Achievement Award at the Living Wage Champions Awards. Meanwhile, she is proudly nurturing a new generation of campaigners. “This campaign has helped people make ends meet,” says -year-old Michael Muthiora. “But the other thing it means to me is that we get to create justice when there is a lot of injustice in the world.”

title: sturgeon praises benefits of aberdeen bypass
story: The First Minister has hailed the AWPR as “transformative” for the region with initial estimates showing the new route has cut journey times by half.Addressing north-east business leaders at Aker Solutions’ office in Dyce yesterday, Nicola Sturgeon said the new road was already delivering “major and signicant improvements” including halving traffic on the old A and reducing travel times around the city centre.Speaking to the Evening Express after the event – which saw the launch of a specially commissioned AWPR-themed exhibition by Scottish photographer Colin Prior – the First Minister said: “We’re already seeing the benefits in terms of reduced journey times. A journey from here to Stonehaven before the bypass took  minutes, today it takes  minutes.“That helps to improve the quality of le for people who have to make that commute regularly by reducing congestion and reducing journey times. It helps to lower emissions as well and brings big economic advantages.“The site we’re on just now, Aker – they made the decision to centralise operations largely because of the AWPR.”Initial monitoring by Transport Scotland found key journey times have been reduced by half, even during rush hour, through the -mile AWPR route between Stonehaven and south of Ellon.The £ million project finally opened to drivers in February after being dogged by a series of delays and contractual problems.Transport Scotland missed its “late autumn” target date and a later aspiration of January due to work repairing defects on the new River Don bridge after cracks were discovered.When askedany lessons could be learned from the handling of the project, Ms Sturgeon said: “While not underplaying these issues, they are not unheard of in big, complicated infrastructure projects. vw, px"  “The AWPR, when it was under construction, was one of the biggest projects of its kind anywhere in Europe.“These things are not unusual – there are issues that will need to be worked through – but in five, ,  years time, I don’t think these will be the things people are talking about but the massive benefits.”Transport Secretary Michael Matheson, who also attended yesterday’s event, said feedback on the route has been “overwhelmingly positive”.He said: “We can now see from the studies we’ve undertaken in recent months since the road was opened that traffic in Aberdeen city centre has reduced by %.“We’ve already had feedback from some in industry who have said, for example, they can see house prices shting in areas that are much more accessible as a result of the road.”Mr Matheson said the cost of the project remained the “exact same” as it had at the outset.He added: “With any additional costs associated with the road, the responsibility lies with the contractors to demonstrate that there’s a process in place to facilitate that and, to date, they’ve not been able to substantiate their claim. On that basis the cost remains as it did at the outset.”

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: thought for the week march 22 2019
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAs a very enthusiastic, though amateur, photographer, I had treated myself to a new and rather expensive camera lens.Usually I purchase an inexpensive skylight filter to protect the lens from scratches or damage.The theory being that it is far easier and less expensive to replace an inexpensive filter than a very expensive lens.However I was intrigued when I began to research the best filter for my requirements.I was being offered a completely clear glass filter for way more than I would normally pay for a simple skylight filter.At first I thought: #Why on earth would I pay such a lot of money for something which is just a piece of clear glass #However when I read the reasons given to purchase this clear piece of glass, I was convinced.The logic was this – why pay a lot of money for a top-class lens, and then put a cheap filter on it Why not let the lens do the job you have paid it to do, and simply protect it with the finest clearest glass you can get.I thought of the words of St Paul who said: #For now we see through a glass, darkly but then face to face: now I know in part but then shall I know even as also I am known.#Somehow my clear glass filter gives me the best image reproduction I can have.In our earthly le, we see Jesus as best we can, perhaps through a skylight filter, but just think that in time there will be nothing to dull our vision and we will see him in all his glory # crystal clear and face to face.

title: letters week 12
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,This is a short note of thanks to all who made my th birthday party at Chalmers Court such a success.I did not help a great deal by having a bad fall near the bus stop on my way for the morning papers and am lucky not to have broken bones. A bruised and battered face caused alarm on first viewing which gave way to quite a lot of laughter and bold comment.But what a delightful party, laid on by our warden Sheena Stewart and ladies and saw we all had tea, coffee, and home baking, including shortbread and sconesand presents of wine and malt whiskey. What a lovely morning.To all who sent cards for my th, including the community council, the Wednesday Club, the Inveraray Highland Games , my warmest thanks. And many thanks to those who helped me up after my fall and in particular Stuart Campbell of Brambles who took me to the surgery, whose very kind people cleaned me up and sent me on my way to my party half an hour later.And a mention to Take the Floor too on Radio Scotland on Saturday night. Thank you Inveraray and District Accordion and Fiddle Club and Margaret Mather our secretary for this request.So I won#t forget my th in a hurry, but such kindness and friendliness cannot be forgotten ever.My thanks to you all,Niall Iain MacLean, InveraraySir,I read with great interest the letter in the March  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser from C Rees, Lochgilphead.In addition to all that was mentioned I wonderyour readers are acquainted with the McCrone Report which was written in the s As I’m sure your readers are aware this was when oil had just started flowing from the North Sea. Mr Gavin McCrone was, at that time, a civil servant instructed to write a report on the possible effects of North Sea Oil on the argument for Scotland’s devolution.This quote comes from a letter written, by Mr McCrone, in April : #The Paper was written over a year ago in the weeks immediately before the February  election. This will be particularly apparent on page  where, of course, the ministerial pronouncements referred to relate to the Conservative Government.#So he was instructed to write this report by a Conservative Government but was reporting to a Labour Government.This quote comes from the end of the letter: #When my paper was written it was classied “secret” and given only a most restricted circulation in the Scottish Office because of the extreme sensitivity of the subject.#The report discussed the possibility of Scottish Independence and came to the conclusion: #What is quite clear is that the balance of payments gain from North Sea oil would easily swamp the existing deficit whatever its size and transform Scotland into a country with a substantial and chronic surplus.#Now, this is a very tiny segment from a document that could have changed our history but that’s in the past and we must now look to the future.What is upsetting is thatthis wealth had been invested in an oil fund or more fairly distributed by the  British Government # either Conservative or Labour # there might not, now, be an upsurge in support for separation from Westminster.Wilma Watts, TarbertSir,With Theresa May’s Brexit deal yet again failing to get through the House of Commons and a delay to the date the UK is due to leave the EU, it is clear that we are simply lurching from crisis to crisis.One wonders what good an extension will actually do given the negotiating position of both the EU and the UK. The UK is deadlocked, in terms of its people, Parliament and Cabinet and the likelihood of any semblance of a deal that command the majority of the House of Commons is unlikely. This is especially true given the deep isions within the Tories, both Remainers and Leavers, as well as opposition from the DUP.Given this situation those like myself have long argued that a UK-wide referendum on the deal, a so-called ‘People’s Vote’, with the option to remain in the EU, is the only credible way to break this deadlock. For those who argue that this would damage our democratic process, I am not sure we can slump any lower than the situation we are currently in.As David Davis, the former Brexit Secretary and an ardent Leaver, pointed out before the EU referendum: #If a democracy cannot change its mind, it ceases to be a democracy.#There are few I know who voted for Brexit in the belief it would make them poorer, and it is up to the public to give its view on whether the deal, and more importantly its implications, are what it wants.For once I agree with Jacob Rees-Mogg who previously supported a vote on the renegotiated settlement. A statement he now curiously seems to have forgotten.The Scottish Parliament has led the way in backing a People’s Vote and now that we know the precise nature of the deal, it is up to the public to have its say.Alex Orr, Edinburgh

story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowFurnace folk woke up on Sunday April  to find that their village was ablaze with colour.Pompom trees, bright flowers up the wall of the village hall and colourful birds nesting in the school garden, and many new residents had joined the community in the form of giant purple caterpillars, huge multi-coloured spiders and a rather odd-looking woman with a face painted by Picasso, knitting nonchalantly outside the village hall.Furnace had been truly #yarn bombed#.This unprecedented wool attack was put together by members of the vibrant Furnace Craft Group who wanted to make their very first Furnace Craft Day one to remember, and with the sun coming out to join in the fun the day was a huge hit with residents as well as many other visitors.Inside the hall visitors were able to browse the many colourful and innovative craft stands, including a visit from Travelling Yarns with their mobile pop-up wool shop selling a vast array of Scottish wools. title: letters to the editor week 18 2
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,I read with interest the article in the April  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser about the council’s autism strategy.I find it strange Councillor Green said the #strategy has reached a draft stage# when an Autism Strategy for Argyll and Bute already exists.It was commissioned by the council, produced in May  and signed off by council members. An implementation plan was produced in December  to cover the years -. Who in Argyll and Bute is responsible for this plan  How many of the outcomes have been achieved As someone who has been involved with autism personally and professionally for many years, I find it extremely disappointing there seems to be an inability by those in authority to get organised enough to address the issues and provide services for autistic people and their families.There is no need for further drafts and consultations.Someone in the authority needs to take responsibility for the existing strategy and implementation plan and get on with it.Maureen Mackintosh, Ardrishaig.Sir,Scotland’s small building firms had a strong start to , in contrast to the UK construction small and medium sized enterprisesector, according to the Federation of Master BuildersScotland.The FMB State of Trade Survey for the first quarter of , the only quarterly assessment of the UK-wide SME construction sector, showed SME workloads declined for the first time in six years.In Scotland, however, there was a jump of  per cent compared with the previous quarter. Thirty per cent of weighted responses were positive, up from  per cent from the fourth quarter of .It is encouraging the Scottish construction industry is bucking the wider Brexit trend with workloads and enquires in rude health. The UK-wide picture is very dferent, with the construction SME sector overall contracting for the first time in six years.Scotland’s good fortune could be due to fewer EU workers being based north of the border compared with other parts of the country, like in London where one in three construction workers are from the EU.Relying less heavily on migrant workers has meant the Scottish construction industry hasn’t fallen foul of thousands of EU workers ing home during the long march to Brexit due to no longer feeling welcome in the UK or sure of their future here.Scotland’s builders, however, must not be complacent. Looking ahead, the First Minister has indicated thatthe UK does leave the EU later this year, she wants a second independence referendum before the next Scottish Parliament election in . This additional political uncertainty, on top of the continued uncertainty stemming from Brexit, could impact on the construction sector in Scotland.The fear is a looming second referendum could test consumer confidence this year and next. For construction SMEs, this is particularly concerning as their prospects are vulnerable to dips in consumer confidence as so much work comes from the private domestic sector.Gordon Nelson, Director of FMB Scotland.Sir,I was joined by my fellow Conservative councillors in Kilmory recently as we discussed atthe numerous challenges facing Argyll and Bute.Ferry sailings, roads, education and the SNP#s late single farm payments were all mentioned.With the SNP hammering local authority spending and cutting our budgets, challenges in delivering services will become more prevalent.Despite this climate of cuts from the separatists, Conservative councillors are delivering for Argyll. This includes extra funding for the Tarbert and Lochgilphead Regeneration Fund, more funding for infrastructure and an increase in roads winter maintenance resources across Argyll.As ever, my fellow Conservatives and I will continue to fight non stop to make sure our rural constituency is not sidelined by this unceasingly urban and separatism-obsessed over centralising Scottish Government.Councillor Alastair Redman, Kintyre and Islands ward.Sir,I photographed this unusual visitor to Kilduskland Road, Ardrishaig, on April . Magpies are not a regular feature in Mid Argyll. We have not seen one in more than  years here.I think I saw a second one, either in pursuit or being pursued.Ron MacInnes, Ardrishaig.PIC:The Ardrishaig magpie, spotted in April. no_aMagpie

title: hope springs eternal just off the argyll coast
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowArgyll marine conservation groups have joined forces to have a chunk of our coastal waters declared a #Hope Spot# # in a first for the British Isles.The breathtaking iety of le and stunning scenery on land which we are familiar with in Argyll is,anything, surpassed under our coastal waters.It is one of the most biologically erse marine regions in Scotland and the UK so a number of conservation groups # CAOLAS, covering the area around Loch Sunart CROMACH, interested in the Loch Craignish area Friends of the Sound of Jura and Save Seil Sound # decided to pursue a Hope Spot for the region.Under the auspices of international marine conservation organisation Mission Blue, Hope Spots are areas of sea around the globe where hope remains. Places where le is still winning.And so the Argyll and the Islands Hope Spot was born # or soon will be, since the formal launch will not happen until June .Speaking at a celebration and unofficial unveiling at Craignish Village Hall on May  was renowned wildle photographer and film-maker John Aitchison, from north Knapdale.He joined a call to action, echoed by other speakers during the evening, to work to create a sustainable future for all species, humans included.#The situation is very stark very clear,# he said. #We cannot delay in improving bioersity in the seas and on land.#He cited the example of the flapper skate, a species found in the Sound of Jura but internationally in such a precarious state that it is now more endangered than the giant panda.Another speaker, tour guide and photographer Philip Price, continued the theme, saying: #Hope Spots represent international recognition of what we have # and what could be here.#But this cannot be a flash in the pan, so the more people who are involved the better.#The upbeat mood in the packed hall was capped with a congratulatory message from Mission Blue founder and president Sylvia Earle.In a special video, she said: #Thank you for being the first # but hopefully not the last # Hope Spot in Scotland and the UK.#There is a chance, thanks to people like you who care.#

title: rusty padlocks no more new owner talks about plans to re open inveraray pier
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThe new owner of Inveraray#s iconic but neglected pier has plans to re-open it to the public # but only after refurbishment work is complete.The pier has been purchased by the Colonsay-based Byrne family, owners of the nearby Inveraray Inn.Earlier this week company director Geaspar Byrne spoke exclusively to the Argyllshire Advertiser about the reasons for buying the pier and what lies ahead.Mr Byrne said: #I have an interest in Inveraray and want to see it doing well. It is obvious to everyone that the pier not being open is a resource wasted.#Inveraray Pier has been in existence since . Comprising an older stone-built section and later timber structure, it was once a thriving hub for Inveraray#s herring fleet and a popular destination for passenger steamers. It was used by everything from pleasure craft to puffers, with the military also making good use of it over the years.In more recent times it has fallen into disrepair and was closed off to public access in the last decade.#When we heard it was for sale we decided to make a bid,# continued Mr Byrne.#It would have been a shame to see it fall into the hands of someone who would want to use it just as a private pier. It#s about securing its future.#The Byrne family intends to re-open the pier for public use # but Mr Byrne is keen to dampen speculation about the potential future uses for the structure.Before anything  happens, the condition of the stone and wooden sections must be assessed, and reports have been commissioned from engineers and conservation architects.#I don#t want to raise expectation unnecessarily, but the most likely scenario is that we look to re-open the stone pier first of all,# explained Mr Byrne.Repairs would be needed to the stone structure and ironwork. New handrails and safety equipment would be needed along with lighting and basic security measures such as CCTV.Beyond that, the future of the wooden pier looks less certain.refurbishment is not an option, alternatives might include floating pontoons, while the potential for dredging around the pier and harbour might be considered.Through an agent, The Argyll Partnership, the Byrne family has contacted the Clyde Marine Planning Partnership with a view to having Inveraray included in the fledgling Clyde Regional Marine Plan, stressing that the pier #represents a great opportunity to contribute to the economic, social and environmental needs of the Clyde Marine Region#.And the new owners have said that the community council, Inspire Inveraray and others from the area will be fully involved as the redevelopment takes shape. The plans are also said to have the backing of the Duke of Argyll.Mr Byrne concluded: #Hopefully local people will want to help and come forward with ideas.#I don#t want to raise hopes at this early stage, but I hope that buying the pier is a good thing to do.#
