title: cycle-planned-as-part-of-georges-legacy
story: SIX months after a fatal accident cut the le short of a popular Melrose student, his family have formed a new charity in his name.After officially launching last month, the George Crawford Legacy Trust has already raised over pound to help local groups.And their next fundraiser is already in the pipeline.Horse riding enthusiast George was only  years old when he was hit by a car while walking back to his university halls last October.He had just started his agricultural studies at Harper Adams University in Shropshire when the accident occurred.After lting the wallet of his friend by mistake during a night out, his ID was incorrectly given by police when he reached the hospital resulting in his parents missing his final hours.More than a thousand people travelled to join them in paying tribute to the talented young sportsman last year.Over  people attended the George Crawford Legacy Trust official launch in Melrose last month.The drink reception held at Georgersquos home was a huge success with the tickets, auction, and raffle money going directly into helping others.And now the Trust has planned a four-day cycle expedition to honour his le.Starting in Melrose the group will cycle all the way to Harper Adams in Shropshire.They will be stopping at the cemetery outside Melrose to pay their respects to George before setting off on the -mile challenge.The Harper Adams or Burst Challenge will be undertaken by  fundraisers between June  and June .Cameron Crawford, Georgersquos father told us: ldquoWe lost our son in a tragic accident in October last year.ldquoTo help us adjust to the new le we have been presented with, we have formed the new charity George Crawford Legacy Trust.ldquoWe are so thankful to everyone who came and supported our launch.ldquoOne of the highlights of the night was when a bottle of whisky donated by our friend and neighbour Doddie Weir was auctioned and raised a fantastic pound.ldquoThis along with the raffle and ticket sales raised a good amount and set the trust on its way.ldquoAs George was a very sociable person and had an affinity with people, we wanted the money to go to help others."Already the trust has donated pound to support Riding For The Disabled in Ancrum for the purchase a new horse named Alfie.And it has given a donation to the Injured Jockeys Fund of pound.Trustees are also getting involved in a project to help youths from disadvantaged urban areas to be trained in pony racing and providing all round horse care.A pilot for the project has been ongoing in London and  young people now work full time within the British racing system.Another goal is to help set up a Scottish and North of England system to help youths break the cycle and find a new le.And also they want to provide a local youngster with a financial bursary to help with sporting goals or educational needs.

title: colour-run-fun-explodes-in-galashiels
story: THERE was nothing black-and-white about Galashiels on Saturday as runners from around the Borders took part in the annual Colour Run.Having been postponed earlier in the spring due to poor weather, the weekends event was held beneath glorious blue skies.And it wasnt long until there were bursts of yellow, orange, green and red brightening up the morning.Around  runners of all ages and abilities took part in the six kilometre course which started and finished at Heriot-Wattrsquos Scottish campus.The course took runners out towards Tweedbank and back again.And all along the scenic course were volunteers armed with bags of powdered, biodegradable paint.Developed in partnership between Heriot-Watt University and Live Borders, proceeds from the event are shared between local charity Live Borders and SANE, a leading UK mental health charity.Live Borders chief executive officer Ewan Jackson told us: ldquoTodayrsquos event has been a great success."It is fantastic to see so many happy faces, people of all ages and whole families join in the fun.ldquoThis is the second year we have run the event and it has grown signicantly in numbers."It is a brilliant occasion that brings the local community together while promoting our commitment to making the Borders healthier, happier and stronger.ldquoA big thanks to the team at Heriot-Watt University and everyone involved in bringing the event to fruition once again.

title: attempted-dog-snatch-at-selkirk-cemetery
story: A PENSIONER had to scramble through a hedge and run for help after thieves attempted to steal his pet dog inside a Selkirk cemetery.The -year-old widower, who we agreed not to name, was visiting the Shawfield graveyard on Thursday afternoon with his pet Jack Russell .Two men appeared from a white transit van, which was parked inside the burial grounds, before one gave chase.The pensioner told us: "There was something strange about them and as soon as one of them starting walking in my direction, for some reason I thought they would be after my dog."I walked faster and faster and headed towards another part of the cemetery, but the man, who was on a phone the whole time, also started walking faster."When I looked round he was getting closer all the time so I climbed through a hedge and headed across the field to a nearby house."He was still coming after us and it was only when I met a couple on the road that he stopped."When I walked back down the road with the couple we could see the man running back to the van... they drove out the cemetery at speed."They could only have been after one thing and that was my dog."The white van is described as having faded lettering on one side.Earlier this spring a Galashiels man had to fight off two dog snatchers during a similar incident in Galashiels.The -year-old was approached by the men, who also appeared from a white van, in Elm Row before they tried to grab his pedigree pug.And during the festive season, Georgie and Ed Bell from near Jedburgh believe their two Border Terriers were stolen during a hunt on the Lothian Estates.There have also been reports of other attempted dog snatches in Kelso and Hawick.The Stolen And Missing Pets Alliancebelieve as many as  dogs are being snatched every week across England, Scotland and Wales.Police Scotland confirmed they have been made aware of the latest incident at Selkirk Cemetery last Thursday.

title: education-bosses-take-i-pad-roadshow-around-the-borders
story: EDUCATION bosses are taking their i-Pad plans for transforming classrooms on the road.Scottish Borders Council unveiled its controversial Inspire Learning programme earlier this year.Despite widespread condemnation of the proposals to plough cash into providing i-Pads for every secondary pupil in the region, as well as shared devices for primary schoolchildren, senior officials are moving the scheme forward.And throughout June they will provide further details of how the pound million transformation programme will work at Area Partnership meetings.There will also be afternoon meetings with members of parent councils.Education councillor Carol Hamilton told us: ldquoWe have recognised that it is dficult for people to understand the benefits of Inspire Learning without actually seeing it and speaking to key officers about it.ldquoWe have therefore decided to hold these events at Area Partnerships in order to give all parents, carers and any other interested parties the chance to come along to find out more about the programme.ldquoAnyone can come along and we are really urging as many people as possible to attend.Venues for the meetings have yet to be confirmed but each of the five will start at pm.TheBerwickshire meeting is on Thursday, June , and the Teviot and Liddesdale meeting is being held on Tuesday, June .The Tweeddale meeting will take place the following day on Wednesday, June , with the Cheviot date pencilled for Wednesday, June .And concluding the roadshow will be Eildon on Thursday, June .Deputy leader Sandy Aitchison added: ldquoLocal Area Partnership meetings are a fundamental part of community engagement and encourage participation in local matters.ldquoIn terms of Inspire Learning, the council has done its utmost to provide information about what Inspire Learning is about - but itrsquos not been easy without being able to have that face-to-face engagement.ldquoThatrsquos where we hope these sessions can help."Going forward, we hope this will encourage more participation and interest in Area Partnership meetings into the future.The Inspire Learning programme has been developed by a partnership between Scottish Borders Council, CGI, XMA and Apple.

title: all-in-one-bus-and-rail-tickets-arrive-in-the-borders
story: TRAVELLING by bus and rail in the Borders has just become a whole lot easier.ScotRail and Borders Buses have teamed up to offer, for the first time, all-inclusive tickets.Passengers can now plan their trips to Edinburgh Waverley from towns such as Peebles, Innerleithen, Hawick, Jedburgh, Kelso and Coldstream with the purchase of a single ticket.ScotRail Tourism Manager Alasdair Smart is confident that: ldquoThe new Borders Explorer ticket will transform the way people travel to and from the Border towns, making it even easier, more connected and convenient."The Borders Railway has been a phenomenal success as it continues to grow in popularity."Customers can leave or board the train at either Galashiels or Tweedbank to board the connecting Borders Bus services.Borders Buses Commercial Manager Sharon Morrison welcomes the integrated travel.She said: ldquoWersquore delighted to be working in partnership with ScotRail.ldquoThe Borders Explorer joint ticket offers users a simple and easy way to travel, not just to and from but in and around the Scottish Borders.The all-in-one ticket includes ScotRail travel to and from Edinburgh Waverley and any Borders Bus to and from Galashiels Transport Interchange to towns and villages throughout the region.The Borders Explorer ticket is available for both peak and off-peak journeys.Both rail and bus bosses believe the all-in-one ticket is the ideal ticket for residents and visitors.And it is hoped that the new deal will tie in with the Midlothian and Borders Tourism Action Groups recently launched phone app.The lsquoScotland Starts Herersquo app provides customers with tours, guides, and local information on things to see and do along the Borders Railway as well as connecting bus routes.Giles Ingram from the Midlothian and Borders Tourism Action Group explained: ldquoVisitors can venture further without needing a car, to explore some of Scotlandrsquos most beautul countryside, famed for its historic houses, food and drink.ldquoTourism businesses throughout the Borders welcome the new Borders Explorer ticket by ScotRail and Borders Buses.The Borders Explorer ticket is available to buy from ScotRail travel shops, on-train or by phone.More information is available at www.scotrail borders

title: galas-geological-genius-set-for-recognition
story: A GALASHIELS teacher who made major contributions to the field of geology has been recognised with a commemorative plaque.Charles Lapworth lived in the town for  years between  and , working as the headmaster at Galashiels Episcopal School and marrying a local, Jenny Sanderson.It was during his time in the Borders that Lapworth developed an interest in geology, frequenting the surrounding countryside to try and comprehend the ground beneath his feet.Lapworth discovered that by identying fossilised plankton-like creatures, called graptolites, in rock formations he could recognise the exact formations of rock in the hillsides.His intensive work around Galashiels led to his publishing, with his friend James Wilson, important papers in the early s.Many of the theories flew in the face of the prevailing geological wisdom of the day but were subsequently proven to be sound.The plaque was placed Old Episcopal School, which now houses the office of Galashiels Social Work Department, as part of the Commemorative Plaque Scheme run by Historic Environment Scotland.The unveiling ceremony was attended by representatives of the town and members of the geological community, including Professor Stuart Monro, former president of Edinburgh Geological Society, who described Lapworth as a ldquoman who made an enormous contribution not just to Scottish geology but to the greater understanding of the subject.A class of pupils from St Peters Primary School were also invited to attend the unveiling, having recently worked on a geology project.The application for the plaque was the work of two retired Galashiels residents, Malcolm Lindsay and David Adamson, who became interested in geology and discovered the connection with Lapworth.Malcolm Lindsay told us: ldquoDavid Adamson and I became fascinated by the work of Charles Lapworth who started his geology studies in our area as an amateurndasha very early example of a lsquocitizen scientistrsquo!ldquoThrough his dedication, brilliance and willingness to challenge previous thinking, he progressed to international eminence in the field of geology - an amazing achievement for a self-taught amateur.ldquoWe were surprised and delighted to discover that his formative work in geology took place during a -year tenure in Galashiels while he was headmaster of the Episcopal School, to learn that he married a Braw Lass during that time and that three of his children were born in the Episcopal Schoolhouse.ldquoHe is possibly the greatest scientist to have graced Galashiels and yet his name is so little known here.ldquoWe therefore wanted to commemorate him in this tangible way.ldquoWe hope that the installation of the plaque at his Galashiels workplace and publicity surrounding it will help increase Lapworthrsquos profile very considerably.ldquoA lecture on Lapworth to the Old Gala Club is planned for later this year.ldquoMany children walk past the Old Episcopal School building every school day.ldquoPerhaps the plaque will stimulate some to find out more and to be inspired by this great scientist.

title: legendary-driver-honoured-ahead-of-museum-opening
story: LOCAL hero, Jim Clark OBE, will be remembered in a special lecture at Chirnside community centre this Monday.Formula One world champion and Indy  winner, Jim is still regarded as one of the lsquogreatest racing drivers of all timersquo.And ahead of the Jim Clark Motorsport Museum opening in Duns this summer, the Chirnside History Society are hosting a talk entitled lsquoThe Jim Clark Storyrsquo.Live Bordersrsquo Learning and Engagement Officer, Kenneth McLean, will host the talk, giving an overview of Jim Clarkrsquos career, from his early le through amateur racing and on to becoming World Champion, and his untimely death in .Fans can listen to the talk at the Chirnside Community Centre and browse the display of artefacts and memorabilia from the upcoming museum on Monday, May .Kenneth said: ldquoThe le and legacy of Jim Clark are extraordinary and a joy to share with community groups across the Borders.ldquoAnyone is welcome to come along on the night to explore some fascinating memorabilia, ahead of the museum opening in summer .Operated by local charity, Live Borders, the motorsport museum will provide an expanded exhibition space to showcase Jim Clarkrsquos race cars, memorabilia, trophy collection, film footage and interactive displays.Looking after the pound.m project is the Scottish Borders Council who have partnered with Live Borders, The Jim Clark Trust and the Jim Clark Memorial Room Trust.Funding for the project has come from a iety of generous sources including the Council, the National Lottery, Museums Galleries Scotland and The Jim Clark Trust.And the latter included a grant from the Fallago Environment Fund as well as inidual donations from around the world.To make way for the new museum, the existing Jim Clark Room closed at the end of May .And now after the redevelopment works, the brand-new museum is scheduled to re-open this summer.No advance booking required for the lecture taking place at Chirnside Community Centre on Monday May  at .pm.Other community groups are invited to get in touch with Live Bordersthey would like Kenneth to lead a talk for them.Find him at enquiries@liveborders.org.uk

title: scottish-borders-refusal-to-provide-vegan-option-left-child-without-free-school-meals-for-3-years
story: SCOTTISH Borders Councilrsquos refusal to introduce vegan lunch options in its schools left a child missing three years of free school meals.A vegan family from the Scottish Borders first tried to acquire free school meals for their daughter in , but were told by the local authority it could not provide vegan options.And the family had to pay for packed lunches despite being entitled to free meals.The case was picked up by Go Vegan World, an animal rights advocacy group headquartered in County Meath, Ireland, and they advocated on behalf of the family to pressure the council into providing vegan school meals.Barbara Bolton, Go Vegan Worldrsquos in-house legal counsel, said: ldquoI was contacted by a vegan parent in the Scottish Borders Council area who was trying to obtain vegan meals in school for her youngest child.ldquoShe had been told by the school that this was not possible. When she contacted the council to press for vegan meals they claimed it was not possible to provide vegan meals that complied with the nutritional guidelines for school meals.ldquoThat is quite clearly incorrect. The British Dietetic Association has long recognised that we can get all the nutrients we need on a fully plant-based diet, at every stage of le.ldquoIf Glasgow and East Renfrewshire councils can produce vegan menus that comply with guidelines, so too can Scottish Borders Council.ldquoAs a result of the councilrsquos refusal, the eldest child of the vegan parent had already missed out on free school meals in P-.ldquoI wrote to Scottish Borders Council challenging their refusal to provide vegan meals, pointing out their legal obligations under human rights and equality law. That letter was sent by email on May .ldquoOn May  the vegan parent had a call from the council advising that they would be providing vegan meals for her child from the following Monday.ldquoThat just goes to show how quickly these situations can be resolved and vegan meals put in place when the rights of vegans are brought to the attention of government body.The mother of the two children, Laura, who wishes to remain anonymous, believes the intervention of Go Vegan World was vital.She said: ldquoAlthough the response of the Scottish Borders Council was disappointing three years ago, we are extremely pleased with how things are now developing.ldquoThey are trying hard to meet our daughterrsquos needs and are offering to have a meeting with us to discuss things further.ldquoScottish Borders Council have been great and very quickly we have a vegan option for our child at her school.Scottish Borders Councilrsquos schools are now able to offer meals such as vegetable pizza, with no cheese, and vegan sausages with baked beans and potato smiles.However, Ms Bolton continued: ldquoWe shouldnrsquot be having to make these challenges for inidual vegan families across Scotland vegan options should be available on the standard menu every day for any child to choose, in the same way that vegan options are available in most restaurants and cafes.ldquoThe public sector is lagging far behind the private sphere in providing for vegans, and in making good plant-based options available to everyone.ldquoIt is essential that vegan children are able to live according to their conviction that itrsquos wrong to use and kill animals, including when theyrsquore in school.ldquoThat means food suitable for vegans must be provided. It is not acceptable that vegan children are missing out on free school meals, or that they are excluded from eating in the school canteen with their friends.ldquoWe should be supporting children who have made a moral decision to avoid animal use and killing, recognising the impact their behaviour has on others. A spokesperson for Scottish Borders Council said: ldquoOur schools are in a much better position to provide nutritionally balanced vegan meals than they were previously.ldquoFor example, we can now buy things like soya milk, hummus and vegan sausages, which werenrsquot available on our order list even a couple of years ago.ldquoAt no point did Scottish Borders Council say a vegan menu canrsquot offer vital nutrients.ldquoHowever, as we did not offer a specic vegan option, offering the child part of a mealwould not have been nutritionally balanced and would not meet her energy requirements.

title: jenna-named-beltane-queen-for-2019
story: YOU donrsquot have to be born into Royalty to be a Queen, not in the Royal Burgh of Peebles anyway.For this town celebrates its own monarch family each year.And on Wednesday afternoon schoolgirl Jenna Jones was proclaimed  Queen of the Beltane Festival.The sun shone in a cloudless sky and townsfolk gathered outside Peebles Community Centre waiting to greet the new Queen and her Court.Cheering schoolchildren applauded as the names of the delighted pupils were announced within the hall, and when it came to the announcement of this yearrsquos Queen, a clearly shocked Jenna threw her hands to her mouth gasping in sheer surprise.The -year-old from Priorsford Primary School told the Peeblesshire News that she feels very grateful and lucky to be chosen.She added: ldquoIrsquom so excited to begin the role of Beltane Queen and all thatrsquos involved.Jennarsquos parents, Lisa and Mike were standing outside waiting to catch a glimpse of their daughter when she exited the community hall. And as she came out the sun wasnrsquot the only thing beaming.

title: galafoot-bridge-works-completed-ahead-of-schedule
story: A pound. million improvement scheme at Galafoot Bridge has been completed.And the A s to two-way traffic from pm thisafternoon.The second-phase of works, which has included heightening barriers, was expected to be completed at the end of this month.Brett Archibald for Transport Scotland said: ldquoThis has been a signicant piece of work that ensures Galafoot Bridge is fit for the future, and itrsquos good news to see it completed ahead of schedule.ldquoThe scope of the improvements grew once it became clear that sections of reinforcing steel in the concrete deck would need to be replaced, so we thank the travelling public and other key stakeholders for their patience while this vital work was carried out.The works were originally programmed as a water-proofing and resurfacing scheme, but examination of the bridge deck revealed a signicant number of defects, which required the development of a completely new and extensive series of works to replace reinforcing steelwork and concrete sections of the bridge.The repairs were undertaken in two phases, with a break to allow for the festive period, from late  and were completed by April .Tom Wallace, Account Manager with the Amey South-East Trunk Roads Unit, said: ldquoWe want to extend our thanks to the local community around Galafoot and road users, for the patience and understanding while this vital work has taken place.ldquoThe support of Transport Scotland, local Councillors, Scottish Borders Council, the emergency services, Borders General Hospital, local businesses and the community has made these often-challenging works possible. Completing this work now ensures the safe reliable operation of this road into the future.

title: 35-year-old-accused-of-weekend-voyeurism
story: A HAWICK man has appeared in private at Jedburgh Sherf Court on a charge of voyeurism.Thirty five year old Tristan McCuaig is accused of gaining sexual pleasure by watching another person naked or engaged in sexual activity.He is also charged with disclosing, or threatening to disclose, an intimate image.The offences are alleged to have happened in Hawick at the weekend.McCuaig made no plea and the case was continued for further examination and he was released on bail.

title: ukulele-club-inspires-next-generation-of-primary-players
story: UKULELE players in Earlston are providing inspiration and instruments for the next generation.The hugely-popular Earlston Club has been raising funds to provide ukuleles to several local schools.Fundraising has involved club nights and other performances.Last year the Earlston Ukulele Clubpresented five instruments to the ukulele club at Howdenburn Primary School in Jedburgh.And EUC members Ian Thomson and Mike Dennison recently attended Stow Primary School to present a further five ukuleles to a group of very enthusiastic P P pupils.Ian and Mike were impressed by the pupilsrsquo keenness.And the club has already purchased a sixth, left-handed ukulele for Stow Primary so that all the children can try their hand.They explained that: ldquoThe ukuleles will provide much greater access to instruments for students.ldquoThey will also be available to a new community ukulele club that is being established at the Stow Community Learning Hub, which is hosted at the school.Members of the EUC are involved in getting the Stow club off the ground as well as bringing along instruments for would-be members to try out.The Scottish Womenrsquos Institute , Lauderdale Over-s Club, the Strumash Ukulele Orchestra from Peebles, the Coldingham Ukulele Club and EUC members have all contributed generously to the schools initiative.The EUC meets every Thursday from pm to pm at the Black Bull in Earlston.And the group welcomes new members of any standard, including complete beginners, to come along and enjoy the friendly atmosphere.

title: hector-and-chris-set-for-st-boswells-concert
story: CELEBRATED musicians Hector Christie and Chris Edwards have teamed up for a stunning new CD.And they are about launch the album Ghaists in the Air at St Boswells later this month.Chris is a well-known and talented multi-instrumentalist. His long term relationship with music includes absorbing styles from Scotland, Scandanavia and Ireland where he lived for several years.Hector was born in Aberdeenshire, raised in Angus and has spent half his working le in the Scottish Borders,where he will be a familiar face to many,who remember the events he organised such as the Sleepytoon Folk Club, the Melrose Music Festival and the Both Sides of the Tweed.He tended to keep his singing in the background then.But not any more.The new CD has won warm praise already with Iona Fyfe - Scots Singer of the year  - commenting: ldquoI love the CD - very lovely instrumentation."An The Living Tradition magazine stated: "...the quality never drops - Hectors distinctive voice and Anguss accent compliment the dialect of the poems".Ghaists in the Air features  songs that began their lives as poems by the poet novelist diarist Violet Jacob .Some had tunes put to them already by a folk scene that had increasingly begun to adopt Violets writings.Hector and Chris will perform Ghaists in the Air at St Boswells Village Hall on Tuesday, may .Tickets, priced at pound, are available for the St Boswells concert via Border Events at www.borderevents or ring  .Doors open at pm.

title: thats-the-spirit-selkirks-first-gin-factory-opens
story: SELKIRKrsquoS first ever lsquolegalrsquo distillery was officially opened on Saturday.Selkirk Distillers have been creating their own gins for just over  months ndash borrowing the equipment and expertise of friends at Strathearn Distillery in Perthshire.But following a crowd-funding campaign the two couples behind the venture moved into a renovated workshop on the Philiphaugh estate earlier this spring.Allan and Jane Walker along with friends David and Susan Myatt have been producing their hugely popular Reiverrsquos and Bannock gins at the distillery over the past few weeks.And on Saturday they held a grand opening party with Philiphaugh estate owner Sir Michael Strang Steel cutting the ribbon.Mr Myatt believes the Selkirk distillery will go from strength to strength.He said: ldquoThere have been a lot of ups and downs getting to this stage but we are here now and we all feel the future of Selkirk Distillers is bright.ldquoWe are really happy with our new home and we plan to gradually step up operations.ldquoWe are extremely grateful to the people at Strathearn who have helped us enormously but now we are working closer to home wersquoll be able to meet demand for our products a lot easier.ldquoAll of our gins and rums sell out almost as quickly as we have been making them.ldquoBy having our own distillery we can increase production much easier and react to demand a lot quicker.The renovated estate building dates back to the s, originally powered by a water wheel, and operating most recently as a plastics factory until a fire five or six years ago.Since moving into Philiphaugh in April, Selkirk Distillers have been producing around  litres of their ever-popular Reiverrsquos and Bannock gins each week.And they have also branched into rums infused with hemp oil.Selkirk Distillers gins and rums are now sold in outlets stemming from Portree on the Isle of Skye all the way down to Holy Island.The Walkers and Myatts also sell their produce at food fayres and farmersrsquo markets all across the South of Scotland.Mr Myatt added: ldquoThe number of outlets who stock Reiverrsquos and Bannock increases every few weeks, and we hope to keep expanding to new areasldquoStobo Castle spa told us that a cocktail they created using Bannock Gin is among their most popular drinks.ldquoWe produced our very first batch of gin in September,  and here we are today with our very own distillery.

title: council-spends-25k-to-silence-former-employee
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council has paid pound, to keep a former employee quiet.A freedom of information request has revealed that the council paid the sum over the last six weeks, in order to get a former employee to sign a non-disclosure agreement.The request has also revealed that Scottish Borders Council has spent pound, of taxpayersrsquo money on so-called lsquogagging ordersrsquo since April .Non-disclosure agreements are contracts which are signed by both employee and employer, and which typically prevent staff or ex-staff from publicising certain information.That information can range from commercially sensitive details, such as innovations or company finances, to anything likely to damage an organisationrsquos reputation.Non-disclosure agreements have also infamously been used to prevent employees discussing allegations of misbehaviour, with a number of high profile cases in the UK making national headlines.A Scottish Borders Council spokesperson said: ldquoNon-disclosure agreementsare included in ious types of agreement entered into by the council to resolve a situation.ldquoNDAs are included for the benefit of both the council and the other party parties.ldquoIt is important to note that an NDA is one part of an overall agreement to settle a dispute, and the majority of any costs will be met from within the relevant servicersquos budget.The contracts are sometimes used when employees and their organisations have reached a settlement to a dispute, such as a claim of wrongful dismissal, without going through a full employment tribunal hearing.Reacting to the payouts, Hawick and Hermitage councillor Davie Paterson said: ldquoI am a bit concerned at the use of no disclosure agreements, surely council tax payers are entitled to a full and comprehensive explanation as to why the council them ldquoThe public, quite rightly, will be asking why do the council have to pay out this money, they may be asking is there something wrong with the management at the top ldquoThe public would love to know why pound, has to be spent to keep a former employee quiet when this admin are making cuts left right and centre, but yet they can find pound, to give to former employees.However, the councilrsquos leader of the opposition, Tweeddale East councillor Stuart Bell, urged a more even-handed approach to non disclosure agreements.He said: ldquoSecrecy by a public authority is sometimes necessary, but any overuse does not reflect well on a public authority which should be committed to openness and transparency. ldquoI read of growing concern about the use of non disclosure agreements across a range of public bodies with Westminster MPrsquos, for example, calling for these to be made lsquoa thing of the pastrsquo.ldquoThat said I donrsquot currently think that Scottish Borders Councilrsquos use of these agreements is particularly out of line with their use by other Scottish local authorities. ,params: .pushldquoInformation is limited by some, for example Edinburgh and Aberdeen cities, refusing to respond to freedom of information requests for details. ldquoBut Glasgow City, who have responded to an FOI, and are a much larger local authority than the Scottish Borders, have applied non disclosure agreements more than six times as frequently as Scottish Borders Council over the last five years.ldquoI am minded, as chair of the councilrsquos audit and scrutiny committee, to discuss with colleagues on this committee whether to suggest we should scrutinise the councilrsquos use of non disclosure agreements. ldquoThis would, of course have to be done in strict privacy, but it might allow some reassurance to the public that these agreements are not being overused.

title: gearing-up-to-get-more-girls-on-their-bikes
story: A PROJECT aimed at wooing women onto the saddle is ing for a second year.Following the success of last years initial Easy Riders project, which encourages women to enjoy cycling, it has ed with a fresh series of rides.Each of the sessions, which are taking place this year around Peebles, Galashiels and Selkirk, is restricted to eight riders.The programme is aimed at improving cycling-confidence, skills and fitness - and is completely free.Peebles based Hillside Outside Ltd, organisers of Tour of The Borders and TweedLoversquos Transcend Bike Festival, are leading the project, alongside award winning cycling tuition providers Ridelines.Director of Hillside outside Ltd Neil Dalgleish said: "We were delighted to get nearly  women across the Borders on their bikes last year, the feedback and the continued progress after the course has just been phenomenal.ldquoA total of  percent of participants now opt for the bike over the car for shorter journeys and over  percent said both their physical and mental health had improved."We are proud to be involved again for  and provide this for even more women across the Borders.The project is once again being funded by lsquopaths for allrsquo and transport Scotlandrsquos ldquosmarter choices, smarter places through the Scottish Borders Council.Courses begin this weekend in Galashielsand Selkirk .The first courses pull into Peebles on June .

title: 30p-charging-netted-less-than-a-third-of-expected-toilet-income
story: THE fate of the regionrsquos public toilets is set to be revealed within the next six months.Last year, Scottish Borders Council voted to explore the privatisation of its public toilets after a damning report revealed that the decision to begin charging p for toilet access had netted just a third of its target.Thep charge for using  of the councilrsquos public toilets in the Borders was agreed by a full council meeting in February , following a report where officers assured members that charging for toilet provision would generate an income of pound, a year.However, the total yearly income was just pound,, leading councillors to vote to consider privatisation as an option for future toilet provision.Officers have been working to identy potential third parties which could take over the network, and they have been consulting with a private company which could oversee the design and maintenance of public toilets in the Borders.Galashiels councillor Sandy Aitchison, who serves as the authorityrsquos executive member for neighbourhoods and community services, told a meeting of Scottish Borders Council on Thursday that work was ongoing.He said: ldquoOfficers continue to work with community groups across the Borders who have expressed an interest in operating this type of facility.ldquoAt the same time, officers are continuing to develop conversations around procurement options, internally, to then engage with third parties externallyldquoWe expect the outcome of that process will conclude in the latter part of this year.ldquoThis will allow members to consider which direction they may wish to take over the servicersquos future.Scottish Borders Council has also published a procurement notice on the Public Contracts Scotland website, asking for interested companies to contact the local authority.East Berwickshire councillor Helen Laing, who originally asked for the update to be brought before the full council meeting, asked in response: ldquoIrsquove had two complaints about the condition of public toilets within my ward.ldquoOne said that the Eyemouth toilets have not been cleaned to a satisfactory condition and were described as lsquodisgustingrsquo, while the toilets in Coldstream were mentioned in a Tripadvisor review which said the user had to wade through waters, the toilet wouldnrsquot flush, the sink was out of order and the disabled toilet was locked.ldquoThe Berwickshire tourist initiatives are making great strides to improve the number of visitors to East Berwickshire and we are being let down by absolutely basic facilities.ldquoCan the neighbourhoods member assure us that immediate steps will be taken to improve the condition of our public toilets before the tourist season gets into full swing To which councillor Aitchison replied: ldquoAs we receive reports then we deal with them. So thereforethere is defects then we need to know about them, so please contact us.ldquoThe fact is that this is a challenge, this is a historical issue wersquore trying to deal with and other authorities in Scotland have simply locked the door and that creates other problems. We are dealing with this, as we agreed previously.

title: council-places-75000-order-for-i-pad-covers
story: AN English company has been given a pound, contract to provide , iPad covers for Scottish Borders Council.The contract, awarded to Nottingham-based tech business XMA, forms part of the councilrsquos poundm lsquoInspire learningrsquo project, which will see every -to- year old Borders school child receive an iPad.As well as every P to S pupil receiving an iPad, which they can take home and use with their family, the tablets will also be bought for P to P pupils at a ratio of one for every five children.In total, , iPads will be supplied to Borders school children as part of a ten-year contract with American technology giant Apple and Canadian firm CGI.A contract notice, published by the local authority on the Public Contracts Scotland website, indicates that the iPads covers will come in either red or black.A spokesperson for Scottish Borders Council said: ldquoThe ground-breaking investment by Scottish Borders Council to transform all schools into world-class digital learning environments is making good progress as teachers start to get their hands on the technology.ldquoThis programme is aimed at raising attainment and supporting equity and inclusion for all children and young people. It is about investing in the learning of our young people and putting them at the heart of education, improving outcomes and success for all.ldquoThe effective deployment of digital technology in schools will ensure our children and young people develop a level of general and specialist digital skills that are vital for learning, le and work in an increasingly digital world.ldquoThis will transform teaching and learning across the Borders for the benefit of all teachers, children and young people.The first iPads were rolled out to teachers in April, so they can get to grips with them and test out the system.S to S pupils will receive their iPads in August.Teachers of P and P pupils will be given the devices in April , and in August of that year the roll out will be extended to P and P pupils, as well as to new S pupils.Neither pupils nor their parents will be able to download apps or games to the iPad, as it will come pre-loaded with the necessary apps.Each iPad will also have a block on harmful websites, which will continue even when connected to wi-fi outside of their school. The block will apply no matter which family member is using the iPad.

title: road-ban-for-galashiels-student-caught-drink-driving
story: A UNIVERSITY student who admitted driving while almost four and a half times the legal alcohol limit has been banned from the road for  months at Selkirk Sherf Court.Tammy Strafford of Bridge Street, Galashiels, already had a previous conviction for drink driving in  which meant she would be disqualied for a minimum of three years.The -year-old pleaded guilty to driving with a breath alcohol count of  microgrammes - the legal limit being  - on the B Clovenfords to Bowland road on Sunday, April .Defence lawyer Ross Dow explained that his client had fallen out with her partner on the night of the offence and had spent "a couple of dficult nights in custody".Sherf Robert Vaughan said that in addition to the -months disqualication, he would defer sentence until August .He also certied her for the Drink Drivers Rehabilitation Scheme whichcompleted at her own expense would reduce theof the ban by  per cent.

title: celebrating-learning-disability-in-the-borders
story: A CELEBRATION of the positive contribution made in the Borders by people with learning disabilities was held last week.As part of Learning Disability Week, the five chairs of the regions Local Citizens Panels staged the celebration in Galashiels.Dozens of people with learning disabilities, along with their families and carers, attended the informative and fun event to share their own stories.And they were told of the achievements of each of the Citizens Panels over the previous year as well as an outline of their aims for the next  months.Local Learning Disabilities champion, Councillor Kris Chapman said: ldquoIt is vitally important that we recognise and acknowledge the ways in which people with a learning disability are active, connected and included in communities right across the Borders and this event was an opportunity to do just that.ldquoThe fact that it was so well attended is testament to the commitment that everyone involved has towards making sure that the voices of people with a learning disability and family carers are heard and that their contributions are both respected and taken into account.ldquoI would like to congratulate the Citizen Panel members on organising such a successful event and for what they have achieved over the past year, which I have seen firsthand as I travelled across the Borders to meet with each of Panels."They are to be commended for all their hard work, and I look forward to seeing their plans come to fruition over the next  months.During the event there was also a special performance by the Keys to Le choir.The choir was set up in August  to give people with learning disabilities the opportunity to meet up and have fun.And their practice certainly made sure of a perfect performance in front of an enthusiastic audience.Jenner Freedman from the Local Citizens Panels said: ldquoThe event was excellent, useful and interesting."I particularly enjoyed hearing how other people were involved in their communities all their stories were very encouraging."I also thought that the Keys to Le Choir was hugely enjoyable."As well as Jenner, who chairs the Galashiels and Selkirk Citizens Panel, there are Steven Oliver , David Learmonth , Rhona Hendersonand Brian Boardman .Steven added: ldquoOne of the perks of being an Local Citizens Panel chair vice-chair is being able to attend these events."They are very similar to the meetings themselves ndash not too formal, but unlike the meetings, the emphasis is on having fun as well."They are also the only chance we get to see and catch up with other members."Therersquos still a lot of negativity towards disability but itrsquos to be celebrated as we can still contribute to society.The Local Citizens Panels are always interested to hear from people who would like to find out more about their work and the positive dference they aim to make.To find out more, visit: www.scotborders.gov.uk lds or contact the Learning Disability Service on  .

title: return-to-braw-lads-is-a-blast-for-town-band
story: THE revival of Galashiels Town Band has begun with a blast.And the musicians will continue their milestone year with a further two performances this week ahead of leading the Braw Lads parade on June .The Town Band was at the forefront of the Spurs Night celebrations last Friday evening.And they will also provide the musical accompaniment for the Threepwood rideout this weekend.On Saturday evening Galashiels Town Band will also perform at their Spring Concert in Trinity Church.But it will be ato duties, after  years, on Braw Lads Day that is creating the most excitement.Band chairman Neal Wade said: ldquoBeing able to take our full place in the Gathering has always been one of our goals and we are so pleased to have reached that milestone this year."While many members have played on the Gala Day over recent years, this year will be the first time in at least  years that the Town Band will lead the Braw Lad and Lass down to the Raidstane."Saturdays Spring Concert at Trinity Church starts at .pm - tickets are available on the door.

title: jayne-makes-it-a-findlay-double-at-gala-scouts
story: A GALASHIELS treasurer has followed in the footsteps of her daughter - by become the Scout of the Year.Jayne Findlay collected the Centenary Trophy last week from former leader of Galashiels Scouts, Stewart Bell.The award had previously been won by Jaynes daughter eight years ago.Mr Bell said: "Jayne has beavered away in the background for over  years, constantly learning new skills as the financial transactions have increased in volume and complexity."Her help has been vital in the running of the group."She is part of the Galashiels Scout family and thoroughly deserves to be recognised for her efforts.Jayne also received a long service award during the AGM from District Commissioner Douglas Allan.The Centenary Trophy was donated to Galashiels Scouts to mark Stewart Bells retirement, and recognises iniduals who have made a positive dference to the lives of others, overcome dficulties or used their time and efforts for the benefit of others.

title: live-updates-as-tearful-theresa-may-confirms-june-7-departure
story: A tearful Theresa May announced she was quitting the job it had been the ldquohonour of my le to hold as she set out the timetable for her exit from Number .The Prime Minister said she will resign as Tory leader on June , paving the way for the potentially brutal contest to replace her to begin the following week.Here are the latest developments:.pmStrong and brave speech by a Prime Minister driven by duty and servicehellip she should be thanked for her tireless efforts on behalf of the country. title: brexit-the-past-seven-days
story: Theresa May has given her resignation speech announcing she will stand down on June .ndash Days to go,Brexit comes on the latest deadline of October .----ndash What happened this week On Tuesday, Mrs May set out her new -point Brexit plan, but it was pronounced dead on arrival by the Tory, Labour and DUP MPs she was trying to woo.Commons Leader Andrea Leadsom quit her job in protest on Wednesday evening, saying she could not bring the new plan forward.Voters went to the polls to elect  UK MEPs for Brussels on Thursday, and the Government announced it had pulled plans to publish the latest Withdrawal Agreement Bill in time for a vote in the first week of June.Friday morning brought Mrs Mayrsquos resignation, with her saying it had been an honour to serve the country she loves.--vw,vw,px, px"Theresa May making her statement outside  Downing Street --ndash What happens next The results of the European elections will be announced in the early hours of Monday morning, with the most votes expected to have gone to Nigel Faragersquos Brexit Party.US President Donald Trumprsquos state visit to the UK begins on June .MPs are on a week-long break for Whitsun, ing to Parliament on June , and the Tory leadership campaign officially starts on June .--vw,vw,px, px"--ndash Good weekNigel FarageThe Brexit Party leader is expected to sweep the board in the European elections and send the most MEPs to Brussels.Following that, he is expected to continue campaigning for Brexit and start the campaign to win seats at Westminster.It is dficult not to feel for Mrs May, but politically she misjudged the mood of the country and her party. Two Tory leaders have now gone whose instincts were pro-EU. Either the party learns that lesson or it dies.mdash Nigel FarageMay , ndash Bad weekTheresa MayThe Prime Minister finally decided to call time on her premiership after unbearable pressure from her party.Her announcement came ahead of the European election results where the Tories are expected to come in fth place and only a fortnight afterthe worst Tory council election results for nearly a quarter of a century.ndash Quote of the weekFormer Conservative prime minister David Cameron saidhe feels ldquodesperately sorry for Mrs May following her decision to stand down.He said: ldquoI know what it feels like when you come to realise that your leadership time has finished, that the country needs a new leader.----ndash Tweet of the weekAndrea LeadsomIt is with great regret and a heavy heart that I have decided to resign from the Government.It is with great regret and a heavy heart that I have decided to resign from the Government. pic fSOXkaqmHmdash Andrea Leadsom MPMay , ndash Word of the weekDignityConservative MPs, including Boris Johnson, Jacob Rees Mogg and Steve Baker, queued up to say Mrs May had left office with dignity..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Brexit: The past seven days

title: urgent-inquiry-into-european-election-debacle-demanded-by-scottish-government
story: An inquirymust be held as ldquoa matter of urgency after EU citizens living in the UK were denied the chance to vote in the European Parliament election, according to Mike Russell.Thousands complained on social media under the hashtag #Deniedmyvote, citing apparent administrative errors by local councils, when they tried to cast their vote on Thursday.In a letter sent to Cabinet Office Minister David Lidington and the Electoral Commission, the Scottish GovernmentrsquosConstitutional Relations Secretary said it was anldquooutrageous deprivation of democratic rights.The number of EU nationals who appear to have been denied the vote today is a scandal. These are people who live and work here. This is their home and they had as much right to a vote as any of us. Serious questions need to be answered. #DeniedMyVotemdash Nicola SturgeonMay , He wrote: ldquoIt is a disgrace that in addition to the uncertainties that EU citizens have had to endure over the last almost three years since the EU referendum, some have been denied their right to vote in the European Parliament election.ldquoWe want EU citizens in Scotland to feel settled and secure, and to continue to feel welcome and valued in Scotland.ldquoThis debacle will do nothing to ease their concerns.ldquoWe also have first-hand reports of EU citizens being unable to vote even though they had completed and ed the forms on time.Mr Russell added any seat secured by a small margin could be impacted by the incident.ldquoI would ask you to investigate the scale of this problem, which may have arisen due to the lack of time in the run-up to the election, he wrote.ldquoI believe it is imperative that an inquiry is conducted into these issues as a matter of urgency.ldquoAny seat that is secured by only a small number of votes could be impacted by this outrageous deprivation of democratic rights.The Electoral Commission said it can ldquounderstand the frustration caused by the situation and attributed the problem to the ldquovery short notice on the UKrsquos participation in the European election.EU citizens must transfer their vote from their member state to the UK in a process that must be done  working days in advance of the poll, a process the Electoral Commission said ldquocould be made easier.Wersquore aware that some EU citizens, resident in the UK, have been unable to vote today and understand the frustration this has caused. Herersquos our statement: https:t.co jziuLNfpic ukgarASJmdash Electoral CommissionMay , It said in a statement issued on Thursday:ldquoWe understand the frustration of some citizens of other EU Member States, resident in the UK, who have been finding they are unable to vote today when they wish to do so.ldquoAll eligible EU citizens have the right to vote in the EU elections in their home Member State.ldquoIf an EU citizen instead chooses to vote in the EU election in the UK, there is a process for them to complete to essentially transfer their right to vote, from their home Member State to the UK.ldquoThis is a requirement of EU law, which species that this has to be done lsquosufficiently in advance of polling dayrsquo.ldquoUK law sets this as  working days in advance of the poll.It added: ldquoThis legal process could be made easier for citizens, and the Commission made the case for doing so following the last EU elections in .ldquoHowever, improvements to the process are reliant on changes to electoral law, which can only be taken forward by Government and Parliament.ldquoThe very short notice from the government of the UKrsquos participation in these elections impacted on the time available for awareness of this process amongst citizens, and for citizens to complete the process..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Urgent inquiry into European election  udebacle u demanded by Scottish Government

title: end of the world cycle event geared down
story: Kintyre Wheelers Cycling Club#sEnd of the Worldevent, on the weekend of May  and , had attracted some leading Scottish cyclists but across all events, on both days, there were less than two dozen entries.Entry was through the British Cycling website and EOTW was strongly promoted, by its founder, KWCC secretary Robbie Semple, at the recent Scottish Cycling Running and Outdoor Pursuits Show in Glasgow.With one Monday left to go on entries, at the KWCC committee meeting, in Campbeltown last Wednesday, it was decided to change the event from two days to Sunday only.Any entrants have been fully refunded through British Cycling.It will also be classed as a closed event, confined to KWCC members only.The confined status would mean that anyone from outwith Kintyre could still take part by paying the £ to join KWCC, which is a big discount on the EOTW entry fee.The format has not been confirmed but KWCC#s provisional plan includes a  mile time trial and a MACC Runway Rush, which is a sprint race, recently pioneered at the opening weekend of the season.The event may close with an Australian Pursuit Race ,members have any cycling left in their legs.An APR is a handicap race with the slowest away first over a shorter distance than the planned six hour endurance event.A KWCC spokesperson said: #Hopefully In the future we can look at organising something bigger.#It simply wasn’t going to be viable. The largest entry we had was  for the Saturday  mile time trial and only four competitors were from outwith the area.#However the closed to club event will be free to club members and anyone who joins will have membership till June .#There will be a practice weekend at MACC on Easter Sunday.#Mr Semple re-founded KWCC nearly two years ago. title: letter machrihanish golf clubhouse
story: In one word Machrihanish Golf Course#s clubhouse should be #traditional# in keeping with the golf course and Machrihanish village.The proposal presented by the current committee falls short.The roof line and pitch are the angle of a Chinese pagoda. Instead of a steep Victorian pitch, the proposed roof design looks like a brim hat with the sides down.The design would look good in Hong Kong or the desert of Arizona—not in Machrihanish sited between a row of sandstone manses and the Ugadale Hotel.On the other hand, the existing pro shop is a perfect example of taste in design.The new clubhouse could copy it using reasonable construction costs, for instance two inch by six inch framing faced with a thin stone veneer similar to the cottages at the Ugadale.That is what visitors and guests want to see, a clubhouse in keeping with #Old Tom Morris#.In the name of good design, change it while you still can.Jim Gubler,Las Vegas.

story: The youngsters join a team of - to -year-olds in an initiative designed to strengthen ties between police and young people, teaching recruits about the duties of officers and encouraging good citizenship.Addressing the audience at the youngsters# passing out parade, PC Karen Cairns, the group#s coordinator, spoke about their dedication, commitment and enthusiasm.The Campbeltown branch was the first in Argyll and Bute and the young volunteers signing up, despite schooling and other distractions, is a tribute to their diligence.People often say there is not enough for youngsters to do in small, rural communities like Kintyre, but here it is the opposite.There are so many activities on offer, from sports clubs to music groups, that young people often have to sacrice some for the others.Our young people have so many opportunities.

title: letter council chiefs remuneration package
story: Last week we read of Argyll and Bute Council increasing the fee for shellfish export licenses to a level which threatens to put some exporters out of business. And this at a time when the UK may well have a particular need for all its exports and entrepreneurs to save us from the direst consequences of Brexit.A few weeks ago we read of how the Minard War Memorial has missed out on essential maintenance funding from a nationwide scheme because Argyll and Bute Council neither made the required application within the stipulated period nor took responsibility for its failure.This week we read that the Argyll and Bute Council#s chief executive received an annual remuneration package of around £,. This must seem to most to be an extremely impressive and generous reward for whatever service that particular gentleman has rendered us.Now, it is a long-accepted ethical principle that in the realm of public service a high level of reward must only follow a high level of service.However, it is not at all clear to me # or I would suggest  per cent of the public # exactly how the chief executive has rendered such a level of service as merits such a high level of reward.Putting it into context: Why was so much public money used to reward the chief executive when it could have been put to such uses as properly repairing Minard War Memorial and easing the financial burden on our entrepreneurs I think thatthe chief executive is to retain any credibility, he has face the public in open forum and answer this question.I really hope that he has the courage to meet that challenge.Arthur McFarlane,

title: thought for the week april 19 2019
story: At the close a two-day retreat in the Vatican for the African leaders, the pope asked South Sudan’s president and opposition leader to proceed with the peace agreement despite growing dficulties. Then he got down on his knees and kissed the leaders’ feet one by one.#I express my heartfelt hope that hostilities will finally cease, that the armistice will be respected, that political and ethnic isions will be surmounted, and that there will be a lasting peace for the common good of all those citizens who dream of beginning to build the nation,# the pope said of South Sudan in his closing statement.People were moved to tears as the elderly pope struggled to get down on his knees to kiss the feet of two rival leaders.He did it to bring peace.During the last week of Jesus# le, he too got down on his knees and he washed the feet of his disciples.Jesus adopted the role of servant to do this menial task of washing feet, which would be less than fragrant having shared the same streets with camels and donkeys who were not exactly house-trained.Jesus also wished to bring peace, to show that we are all equal in the eyes of God.Today we stand silent as we think of Jesus dying to show how much God loved us.But on Sunday morning, as we see once again those footprints in the dew, we rejoice that our Lord is risen – to show how much God loves us.

title: lensman focuses on lyrical landscapes in campbeltown talk
story: Dougie Cunningham spoke to Campbeltown and Carradale#s camera clubs, as well as invited guests, about his recently published guidebook, Photographing Scotland, at the Ardshiel Hotel#s Arran lounge recently.Dougie entertained a capacity crowd for nearly two hours with the tale of producing his -page book, which is illustrated with  photographs.Dougie said: #My contract with the publisher was for two years from start to finish but they were understanding and it spread to four years.#It involved travelling thousands of miles in two motorhomes and umpteen ferries.#Although the initial contract took four years to fulfil, it was the impetus Mr Cunningham needed to start travelling round the nation#s best landscape locations.He said: #I sold my car and bought a VW T builders# van and spent another £ making it roadworthy. As it was blue my young niece named it Sully from Monsters Inc.#The van became his base for the multiple trips but proved quite unreliable with many calls to the RAC. Mr Cunningham also found Scotland is a vast country.#Scotland is not small as everyone says,# said Mr Cunningham, #I remember the words on the floor of Central Station # #Scotland is the Best Small Country in the World,# # it is not when you are in a campervan stuck behind a car towing a caravan heading to the far north.#The van broke down on Barra and the RAC rules are that it has to be towed by an authorised RAC garage.#I called up and the operator said go back and wait in your van and we will have someone out to you in a few hours.#I was quite sceptical but after a couple of hours a white  van turned up and one of the men who emerged askedI had tried turning the key.#It dawned on me that they were not mechanics and the other said they had been sent by an RAC garage in South Uist with instructions to push me onto the ferry.#Just down the hill, towards Uig on Skye, Sully#s head gasket went and once again I ed to Glasgow with the RAC and the van in bits.#I had seen so many RAC vehicles the next van I bought was bright orange and my niece named it Nemo.##Perhaps one of the most beautul places I photographed was Islay. So many distilleries which it would be rude to drive past.#Mr Cunningham added: #When I have an opening night at an exhibition it is a great way of spending £ on wine for a bunch of people you are never going to meet again.#The highlight of Scottish landscape photographer Dougie Cunningham#s visit to Kintyre was being snapped with Carradale#s most famous resident, Neenie MacDougall. Rachel Grant on the right has been accompanying Mr MacDougall to Carradale Camera Club for  years. _cphotographer_Neenie_MacDOugall

title: down memory lane april 19 2019
story: It told the dramatic story of the rescue of six crewmen, from tugboat the Tynesider, after leboats, from Campbeltown and Tighnabruaich, were scrambled at am together with an air sea rescue helicopter from Prestwick.Jim McPhee, of Kintyre Hire, who was a leboat man for more than a quarter of a century, has an archive from his many years# service and a photograph from the night.The photograph which was not published in  shows the stricken tugboat Tynesider, aground, two miles south east of Tarbert  years ago.The Tynesider, on charter from Tyne and Wear Tugs, sister company to Glenlight Shipping, was on route from Troon to Ardcastle near Lochgair.She was due to uplt a barge of logs bound for Ardrossan, when she grounded on Skate Island in Lower Loch Fyne.The tug boat the Flying Childers was brought in from Greenock to assist with the rescue operation. Three attempts were made to remove the Tynesider from the island, however heavy weather pushed her further onto the rocks.Divers with portable pumps were drafted in to keep the water level down and successfully pumped out the accommodation level and down to the engine room.On Tuesday April   the anti-pollution tug, the Flying Phantom arrived from Greenock to assist the fourth attempt to pull the Tynesider off the rocks.At .am, the Tynesider, listing on her side, was successfully pulled from the rock. But within a short space of time she went down by the stern.At the time a spokesman for Glenlight said: #Divers examined underneath the tug but could find no sign of damage.#There is no pollution at the moment and it is now in the hands of insurers.#The six crew were rescued by the Campbeltown leboat and taken to Tarbert.In a complication, while the rescued men were being collected by an ambulance, a member of the leboat crew felt ill and he was taken to hospital, where it turned out he had suffered a heart attack.Mr McPhee#s Coxswain#s Certicate of Service, presented on January  , records that during his leboat service at sea  lives were saved.The Tynsider is battered and two crewmen can be seen in the sea. _crnlicert_Jim_McPhee

title: thank you for your support april 26 2019
story: Thankfully Mark was found safe but is taking some time off to recover.What is wonderful in times of need like these is how people rally round, and it was heartening to have so many people show their concern for Mark#s wellbeing.Staff in other Courier departments and offices helped out practically and provided emotional support.Freelance reporter Joan Crooks came into the office minutes after being askedshe could lend a hand and photographer Kenny Craig stepped in at the last minute to cover weekend jobs that the Courier reporter was unable to attend, taking many of the photographs across the news and leisure pages.Former news editor Joanne Simms ed to her old beat to help with this week#s paper and her experience and connections cannot be undervalued.The Campbeltown Courier and its staff are very much part of this community and we greatly appreciated all your support.

title: stand by for another regatta
story: Kintyre Sea Sports, working  in conjunction with Dalintober Beach Group and many other local groups, will be staging Campbeltown Community Regatta again this year # after all the good work last year the  event is eagerly anticipated.The  regatta will take place on Saturday August  from am till pm and there will be opportunities for everyone to try out a iety of sea sports and beach activities.The sea sports on offer will be canoeing, dinghy sailing, kayaking, sailing in larger yachts, stand-up paddle boarding, sub-aqua ing, in the pool at Aqualibrium and wind surfingconditions permit.There will be beach games again on Dalintober Beach.A spokesperson for the regatta team said: #It is an opportunity for everyone to try out these activities and also a chance for those already proficient to join in with others having fun on the water or on the beach.#It is open to local people and visitors of all ages from five upwards, but remember that some activities will have age limits on them and will be available to those of eight-years-old or more.#And, best of all, the sports are free for all participants.There will be refreshments available at very reasonable rates on Dalintober Beach and at Campbeltown Sailing Club.More details will be revealed as the big day approaches, so keep an eye on the Courier and the Kintyre Sea Sports web page, where, closer to the event, there will be an online booking form.

title: letter scots builders buck trend
story: Scotland’s small building firms had a strong start to , in contrast to the UK construction small and medium sized enterprisesector, according to the Federation of Master BuildersScotland.The FMB State of Trade Survey for the first quarter of , the only quarterly assessment of the UK-wide SME construction sector, showed SME workloads declined for the first time in six years.In Scotland, however, there was a jump of  per cent compared with the previous quarter. Thirty per cent of weighted responses were positive, up from  per cent from the fourth quarter of .It is encouraging the Scottish construction industry is bucking the wider Brexit trend with workloads and enquires in rude health. The UK-wide picture is very dferent, with the construction SME sector overall contracting for the first time in six years.Scotland’s good fortune could be due to fewer EU workers being based north of the border compared with other parts of the country, like in London where one in three construction workers are from the EU.Relying less heavily on migrant workers has meant the Scottish construction industry hasn’t fallen foul of thousands of EU workers ing home during the long march to Brexit due to no longer feeling welcome in the UK or sure of their future here.Scotland’s builders, however, must not be complacent. Looking ahead, the First Minister has indicated thatthe UK does leave the EU later this year, she wants a second independence referendum before the next Scottish Parliament election in . This additional political uncertainty, on top of the continued uncertainty stemming from Brexit, could impact on the construction sector in Scotland.The fear is a looming second referendum could test consumer confidence this year and next. For construction SMEs, this is particularly concerning as their prospects are vulnerable to dips in consumer confidence as so much work comes from the private domestic sector.Gordon Nelson,

title: letter letters from alex orr
story: In March you published a letter from John R Newall pointing out how inappropriate he thought it that the Courier chose to publish letters from an Alex Orr of Edinburgh when these letters were political promotional material from a professional organisation, promoting the SNP and would have been better published in a national newspaper.As I was quite sure Mr Orr is not a reader of the Courier I replied to him personally by Royal Mail at the Edinburgh address he provided with his letter. All I added was the post code for that address.Today my letter was ed to me, stamped #Not known at this address#.It appears that not only is Mr Orr misrepresenting himself as a private citizen in his letters to the Courier, even his address is fake.Brian Gee,

title: leader may 3 2019
story: The trial this week of video-link consultations with an NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde consultant orthopaedic surgeon for five Campbeltown patients could be the first step in changing that.People#s time is valuable and the Skype-like calls mean that neither the patients nor the medical professionals have to travel for hours to attend appointments.The cost to both iniduals and the NHS of patients travelling to Glasgow via bus and plane must be signicant.And there has never been greater awareness of the issue of climate change, with the recent Extinction Rebellion protests in London making national headlines.Thousands of protesters blocked off roads in the capital city and called on the government for action to reduce carbon emissions to zero by .The wonders of modern technology could provide a win-win solution # giving people easier access to medical care as well as reducing carbon emissions.

title: letter insufficient consultation on pylon scheme
story: I was out and about in Tarbert recently getting updated by my constituents and local businesses on many pressing local issues.With the village of Tarbert heading into the busy tourist season, the lack of parking spaces in certain areas will become more and more prevalent, all the more so with the ever increasing amount of traffic going towards Islay.I will continue to seek local advice on how to resolve Tarbert#s parking challenges and make sure they are relayed on to our roads department.While the upgrades to the electrical grid capacity are much needed I have been listening to concerns about the plans to erect numerous huge pylons along the picturesque Tarbert skyline.Many locals have commented that there has been insufficient public consultation and many of my constituents have pointed out that with some changes to pylon positioning much of the adverse visual impact could be mitigated.I have also been sent pictures and videos of the cemetery road which has numerous large potholes and craters.Many Tarbert residents have informed me thatwe, in the council, cannot help to provide a solution then a community solution should be looked at.It was great to catch up with local residents in Tarbert and I look forward to being back there very soon.Coucillor Alastair Redman,

title: doncaster man drink drove through town
story: Dan Kharakoz, , of  Princes Crescent, Doncaster, appeared before Sherf Patrick Hughes in Campbeltown Sherf Court on Thursday May .He pleaded guilty to driving the vehicle in Shore Street on August  last year, without insurance and with mg of alcohol in ml of blood, exceeding the mg limit.Procurator fiscal depute Sarah Healing told the court that police officers investigating an unrelated traffic incident saw Kharakoz driving a blue BMW into a parking space. When they spoke to him, they smelled alcohol on his breath.He failed a roadside breath test and was arrested and taken to Campbeltown Police Office where two blood samples were taken as the breathalyser was not working.Defence agent Stephen MacSporran said: ‘Mr Kharakoz hadn’t driven any great distance but he knows he shouldn’t have done so without insurance or while under the influence of alcohol.’Sherf Hughes imposed a £ fine for the lack of insurance, a £ fine for drink-driving and banned Kharakoz from driving for  months.

title: graphic letter made woman feel physically sick
story: John McFarlane, , of  Tormhor, Carradale, pleaded guilty to two charges of behaving in a threatening or abusive manner after delivering the graphic, sexual written communication to the man on December  last year, and the woman on December .He appeared in Campbeltown Sherf Court before Sherf Patrick Hughes on Thursday May .Procurator fiscal depute Sarah Healing told the court that McFarlane regularly gave the man and woman lts to and from Campbeltown.During one of the journeys, McFarlane gave the man a bag of sweets and a letter, on the back of which was written ‘Christmas Day’. A few days later, when giving a lt to the woman, he gave her a box of chocolates and a letter, also marked ‘Christmas Day’, and told her not to open it until December .Coincidentally, both the man and the woman opened their letters on December  and discovered that the contents related to sexual activity between a father and daughter.Ms Healing chose not to read the letter out in court due to its graphic detail.The man was so shocked by the letter’s contents that he ripped it up and texted McFarlane telling him of his disgust.On December , the man accepted another lt from McFarlane and was given a second letter, containing the same material, and was asked to read it out loud in the car.The woman eventually told her family and her daughter reported the incident to police on January  this year.Sherf Hughes deferred sentence until May , when mitigation will be heard for a criminal justice social work report, a restriction of liberty order assessment and a psychiatric report to be carried out.

title: waverleys manager dismisses sabotage claim
story: Paul Semple has confirmed that the only reason the vessel will not sail this year, for the first time in  years, is because the ship#s boilers need replacing.Manny Singh, operations director of pressure group All Under One Banner , told the Courier last week that he believed the withdrawal of the steamer, which had been privately booked to take people to an independence march in July, was #a backhanded way of trying to sabotage the numbers appearing# at the demonstration.Mr Semple told the Courier: #I can totally dismiss any suggestion that the Waverley has been withdrawn from service in an attempt to sabotage the independence march.#All involved with the Waverley are deeply saddened that the ship is unable to sail this season. The steamer’s future is under threat and without support at this time Waverley may never steam again.#As part of the ship#s winter maintenance programme work on the boilers has been ongoing since February and it was following extensive consultation and investigation that it was concluded that the boilers must be replacedWaverley is to sail again.Mr Semple added: #We are currently scoping the full works required to replace Waverley’s boilers andher to service. Once we have full costings, we will be launching an appeal.#We are very grateful for the donations received since the ship’s withdrawal from service was announced. It is clear from the support so far that many people want to see this iconic steamship sail on for many more years to come rather than become a static exhibit.#Donations can be made via the registered charity#s website at waverleyexcursions, by calling    or by texting STEAM followed by a donation of £ or £ to .

title: headteacher-chosen-for-newly-merged-primary-school-in-prestonpans
story: The new school is a merger of Prestonpans Primary School and Prestonpans Infant  Nursery School.Neither of the current headteachers ndash Sheila Laing from Prestonpans Infant School and Jonathan Revell of Prestonpans Primary ndash applied for the new position.East Lothian Council has now announced that the post has been given to Alison Cookson and she will take up the role in August.Fiona Robertson, head of education with the council, said: ldquoAlison Cookson is an experienced headteacher who has most recently worked as the interim chief executive Officer to Salford Academy Trust [in Greater Manchester].ldquoShe joins Prestonpans at an important stage in the schoolrsquos development and will lead a transition group involving staff, parents and pupils to establish one learning community from early years through to P.Sheila Laing is staying with the council ndash she is taking up a new lsquovirtual headteacherrsquo post in the county for looked-after and care experienced young people, starting in August.Ms Robertson added: ldquoThe virtual headteacher post is a first for East Lothian and follows successful pilots in other areas, including Aberdeen.ldquoThis is an important role to champion the needs of care experienced young people and ensure that they receive support to improve their le experiences and educational outcomes.ldquoIt will involve working with a wide range of key partners, young people, carers and agencies to develop and implement a strategy to put in place the best possible outcomes for care experienced pupils.ldquoI am delighted that we have appointed Sheila to this role and that her enthusiasm, professionalism and experience will support and drive forward this important work.The virtual headteacher role is funded for two years through Scottish Attainment Challenge Funding.

title: golfers-surprise-as-he-finds-guinea-pig-on-golf-course
